social_posts.post_text:
I know because I did it…🙋🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
The dude I was dating (my now husband 😂) was everything I wanted. He is smart and funny, he’s humble and dedicated. He’s the perfect mix of adventurous and introverted. He’s affectionate, articulate and loves HARD. There was no way I was going to walk away from him because he had a child. But how could I show him I could fit into his world? How could I show up for him and “prove” I could be a partner in life and in parenting? ⁣
⁣
I cannonballed into stepmotherhood. I was super stepmom with the snacks, the birthday parties, the picking up from daycare and bedtime stories. ⁣
While I was capable and willing to do all these things - I was not aware of boundaries, my own comfort levels, and expectations. This later led to  resentment and burn out. ⁣
⁣
Many of us get so blinded by the urge to “prove” ourselves that we neglected ourselves. It isn’t until later when we start to see what truly aligns with how we WANT to show up and what NEEDS to be adjusted. ⁣
⁣
So to new stepmoms - I see you. Here’s a little nudge letting you know you have nothing to prove. Move forward in your relationship first - let parenting come gradually. To the seasoned stepmoms who like me, jumped in with a splash - have the courage to assess your role and rebuild to the standard that fits you, not what’s expected of you. ⁣
⁣
You are enough - boundaries and all.😘⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

😎New Episode! ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I chat with Ashley-Nichole who shares her experience of having multiple stepmoms and how it's shaped her role as a stepmom to her two bonus-daughters. We discuss holding the title of "stepmom" without a marriage certificate, finding her "place" in her home and what led her to writing a children's book, "Wicked Awesome Stepmother". Disney did us dirty, but Ashley-Nichole is confronting that narrative! Listen in! ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
About My Guest: ⁣⁣
Ashley-Nichole was raised by her mother and stepmother in Ft. Myers, Florida, but it wasn't until she became a stepmom, herself, that she drew inspiration for her first children's book, Wicked Awesome Stepmother. She is passionate about creating stories that will give a voice to children and families of non-traditional backgrounds by sharing messages of inclusion, understanding, empathy and kindness. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
@wickedawesomestepmother⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🎧Listen wherever you listen to podcasts! ⁣⁣

We have to focus on what we can control… ⁣⁣Ourselves. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Identifying what we’re feeling can be difficult. Being able to communicate it to others is even harder. “𝘉𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘥𝘢𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘴” can feel overwhelming and uncomfortable - especially if you’re doubting your “right” to enforce them. We’ve ALL needed to use these skills before —but once you become a stepmom, you are using them on the daily and you need to get good at it. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Get good at knowing what you feel and why. Become a pro at effectively communicating your emotions and advocating for your boundaries. NO ONE ELSE CAN DO THIS FOR YOU, it’s up to you babes. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
HOW?? Begin asking yourself questions:⁣⁣
• Why is this making me upset?⁣⁣
• What feels uncomfortable about this? ⁣⁣
• What hope or expectation did I have?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Journaling, voice memos, talking with a trusted friend or therapist can all be great ways to become more aware of your feelings and find the way to articulate them to those who need to hear it. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You could wait for things to change in your blended life. You could expect others to just know what you feel or need. You could succumb to the thought that this is just the way it is… ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Or you can realize the power to your happiness is in your hands, if you choose to take it. 😘💪🏻⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣

Or “joint” anything, really… 😖⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Even if you have a good relationship with the ex, interactions or social gatherings may cause some pit sweat. 😂 If you have a high conflict situation - well that’s a whole different level of anxiety. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I have worked with many new stepmoms who stepped into an already established tradition of joint holidays. Their partner and the ex made a commitment to one another to “keep things normal” for the kids. Okay, great in theory… but what happens when one person moves on and enters into a new relationship? Awkwardness… that’s what happens. And the opportunity for the stepmom to look like the bad guy ruining Christmas with her feelings and boundaries. 😒⁣⁣
⁣⁣
To those who do joint holidays - what’s that like 👀. Who had to stop the joint stuff and create your own traditions? Who’s still trying to create some separation? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Wherever you’re at on the spectrum - sending love, strength and peace. ⁣⁣
⁣
✨Swipe for Bonus ⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Who else wants a little justice? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣We see the disrespect, the chaos and sometimes even neglect. Yet to everyone else she’s a caring, calm and loving mom who’s always a victim of her co-parenting dynamics. She gets the praise and support - “it must be so hard to share your kids”… meanwhile the stepmom gets glares, judgement and blame. ⁣
⁣
If only they knew how she REALLY is. ⁣
⁣
It’s especially frustrating knowing that while the kids SHOULD worship their mom, we are here witnessing her parenting choices and even the damage she’s causing. In some ways we want to protect them - but parts of us hope they someday see the truth. ⁣
⁣
It’s a hard dynamic, Mama’s. I know every time you see her post a perfect photo on Facebook you want to scream. I know when you show up to every sporting event with little recognition and she shows up to one and gets a parade, you want to just quit. ⁣
⁣
It’s not fair. And we all want a little bit of justice. Maybe it will happen, but my question is:⁣
Will we be okay if we never get it? ⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

I wish our partners knew the unique feelings we carry…⁣♥️
⁣
I wish they understood the feeling of being uncomfortable in your own home. What it’s like to feel like your every move is open to criticism. I wish they understood the feeling of wanting so badly to love and be loved in your family - but feeling like you’re not a priority and love is conditional. We’d like to believe that if they knew how we felt - things might be different. FEEL different. ⁣
⁣
But the reality is…our partners may never understand what it’s like to walk in our shoes. They have a unique experience too. But I’m here to tell you - we don’t necessary have to understand someone in order to offer loving support. ⁣
⁣
Keep trying. Keep finding ways to express yourself and what your experience is like because it’s valid. ⁣
⁣
This is worth repeating: Your experience is VALID regardless if someone understands it. ⁣
⁣
You’re not alone, babes. ⁣
What do you wish your partner understood?⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣

A holiday post tradition 😂🎄⁣
⁣
It would be some straight Christmas magic if we got through the holidays without all the (unnecessary) blended family drama. ⁣I just want to stick to the schedule, not deal with the petty antics and well, just be left alone. Who’s with me? ⁣
⁣
All that to say - I’m applauding myself for how I’m managing. I’m opting out of doing things that would just lead to resentment. I’m putting my energy on the things I truly care about… and I’m choosing laughter over anger and tears. Where’s my trophy? 🏆⁣
Stay strong, sisters. We got this. ⁣
⁣
On a different note - what have you asked Santa for this year? What gift are you really excited to give? 🎁⁣
⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣

If “evil” is having boundaries and a voice then… 😈⁣
⁣
I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t like my SS in our bedroom. I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t always agree with my partner’s parenting decisions. I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t want to be friends with the ex. I’m a good stepmom AND transition days make me anxious, I love my “down time” and I don’t want every vacation to include my SS. ⁣
⁣
I’m not a good stepmom in spite of these things.⁣
I’m a good stepmom BECAUSE of them. I can be commited to my sweet little family and still have feelings, hopes and dreams, opinions,  goals, and amazing f*cking boundaries. ⁣
⁣
Stepmoms get ridiculed and judged if we don’t appease everyone, love our stepkid, want to be buddies with the ex, voice an opinion or just… exist. It can be tempting to just keep quiet, get smaller, abandon boundaries… but if we do then we risk losing ourselves in the process. Then what? Remember - you matter and you weren’t meant to be it all, solve it all or live up to everyone’s expectations. ⁣
⁣
We’re not evil; We’re radical. ✨⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Holding space for your happiness and grief…♥️⁣
⁣
I am deeply in love with my husband. There’s not a single doubt in my heart that I’m meant to be with him. But the stuff that comes with that is hard and heavy. ⁣
⁣
I didn’t want to be doing mom things at 26. I wanted to experience all the firsts with the person I love. I didn’t want my life to be dictated by a legal document. I wanted “normal” and “traditional”.⁣
⁣
I love my partner and I love the life we’ve built, despite the tough stuff. But I have to feel balance for it to feel “worth it” and I wrestle with guilt and doubt. There are days when I’m overwhelmed with gratitude and happiness, and mourning the life I won’t have. I chose this, yes. But if I had my choice again would I choose different? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Stepmom if this resonates I see you. Know that it’s okay to feel it all. You’re human. It’s okay if you’re deeply happy, but still wouldn’t choose hard again. ⁣
⁣
⭐️Now… to lighten things up… swipe for a bonus post 😘⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

🎄to get you in the holiday spirit! 😂⁣

I post this every year and it always ruffles some feathers but oh well…
⁣
The holidays can be a joyous time of year - but for many of us we’re managing stress, the fear of the ex fucking shit up and that damn Elf on the shelf… 🙃⁣
⁣
Here’s your reminder to take a breath. Seriously… do it right now. ⁣
Breathe in….⁣
And out…⁣
Relax your shoulders, unclench your jaw…⁣
Put down whatever you’re carrying and remind yourself that what you’re doing is enough. YOU are enough. ⁣
⁣
Lower your expectations…⁣
Only do what fills your cup…⁣
Don’t let the grinch steal your holiday. ⁣
⁣
What do you need today? ⁣
⁣🎅🏽🎁🎄⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣

Be loud, you’re not alone, we’re in this together….⁣
⁣
I didn’t know being a stepmom would come with so many challenges. Met a guy with a kid? Cool! Kids are fun! Have an ex? We all do. NBD. Oh my sweet naive soul… 😂⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I thought the challenges I was facing and the feelings I was having made me a bad person. I thought that it meant we were doomed and I was obviously not cut out for this stepmom gig. But I was also deeply in love with my guy, and I so badly wanted the family we were creating. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I had to learn and accept that both can be true. You can be annoyed and irritated, sad and grieving… but still hold joy and want to show up every day for the family you love. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You can feel it all and still be right where you’re meant to be. ♥️⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

A few years ago my husband said something pretty powerful…⁣
⁣
After one of my “why doesn’t she just give me a chance - I’m not a terrible person!!” rants, he looks me dead in the eye and said, “Babe, that’s what she’s afraid of.” He went on to say that it was probably easier for her to make me a monster in her head, and if she actually got to know me she would humanize me… maybe even LIKE me. 😱The horror! ⁣
⁣
This concept released me. Released me from the burden of trying to gain her approval. Released me from constantly wondering what I’ve done wrong or what I’ve done to deserve this - nothing and oh, nothing. He was right. If she got to know me, heard me out, saw me as a loving person in my SS’s life or even a loving person to my husband - well, she couldn’t handle it. I’m the villain in her story - and she’s committed to that narrative.⁣
⁣
I know it sucks to feel misunderstood and hated. I know you’re frustrated because you want to share your side of the story. I know you’re ruminating - knowing you would never behave like her. I get it…but I truly feel they’re choosing to see what they want to see, so nothing you do will change that. Only they can decide to change and I’m not holding my breath for that… are you? 😮‍💨⁣
⁣
Keep being amazing.💁🏻‍♀️⁣
Keep showing up and rocking it. 😎⁣
Keep your head high.👑⁣
Haters gonna hate.😘⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

⭐️New Episode⭐️⁣
⁣
I welcome Dr. Amy Baker to discuss parental alienation, what it is and best practices on how to navigate it. What does the research say about alienation and how to stay connected to the kids? How do grown kids reconcile with their alienated parent? Amy discusses her work and the books you can read now to help guide you through this difficult road. Listen In!⁣
⁣
About My Guest: ⁣
Dr. Baker has a PhD in developmental psychology and is the author or co-author of 9 books and over 100 journal articles. Her books include "Adult children of parental alienation" "Co-parenting with a toxic ex" and "surviving parental alienation." Dr. Baker has served as an expert witness around the country, offers training for legal and mental health professionals, and provides individual telephone coaching for targeted parents.⁣
⁣

Maybe you need this reminder too 😘⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Your peace is worth protecting. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
If you’re feeling the weight of the world right now here’s your reminder to set stuff down. You don’t have to fix it all. Stop future tripping or worrying about things beyond your control. Take a breath. Consider what you need and make it happen. ⁣
⁣
It’s a privilege to get your energy - make sure they deserve it. ⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣

If you haven’t heard it enough - you stepmom, are magical and appreciated. ⁣
⁣
To the stepmoms who have done all the gift buying and wrapping 👏🏼 To the stepmoms who have moved that damn elf every night 🏆 To the stepmoms who are feeling the pressure to create holiday magic when you’d rather just not 🥇. ⁣
Put a bow on your head babes, you’re the real gift and don’t forget it. 🎁⁣

Ah yes… the classic inflexibility accusation. 🙃⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Raise your hand if you’ve ever heard “well you never said no before you got your little girlfriend.” 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
What she meant to say was, “I once was able to control you and now I can’t.”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Especially around the holidays schedules are being shifted and “favors” are being asked. While it is the season of giving and there should be a level of flexibility, saying “yes” should not be said at the sacrifice of boundaries or a form of control.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Sending love to all of you who navigate this. Those who are trying to be reasonably flexible but are forced into manipulative conversations. Those who are trying to hold their boundaries but are being made to be the bad guys. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Do what’s best for your home. Stay strong as a couple and see through the words she’s saying.⁣⁣
You aren’t alone. ⁣⁣
⁣

Many of us operate in the belief that if we….⁣
⁣
can plan it, predict it, prepare and get ahead of it… we can control the outcomes and protect what we value most. ⁣
⁣
We lay in bed at night wondering how or when she’ll respond to that email. We try and foresee what she’ll do next to ruin the happiness in your home. You’ll anxiously talk to your partner about what you’re anticipating and hoping for validation and reassurance only to be told “you’re overthinking”. ⁣
⁣
They’re not wrong. You are. But it’s not that simple. ⁣
⁣
When we are trying to protect our home and happiness how can we not feel on guard? We want to feel prepared and in control….⁣
⁣
CONTROL. There’s the word that I latch on to. What can I can control? What power am I granting her as I lay awake at night? Is “feeling prepared” more valuable than enjoying an evening with my partner? What do I really have control over? ⁣
⁣
Overthinking is going to happen. Notice where it’s coming from and what your core need is. Ask if it’s in within your control. Soothe yourself in saying “whatever happens…we’ll handle it.” Take your power back. ⁣
⁣
Who’s overthinking right now? ⁣
What’s your core need? ⁣
 ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

There’s room for all of us, and you’re safe here. 😘⁣
⁣
Years ago when I first started searching for stepmom resources and guidance I kept coming across messages like “love them like your own” and setting the expectations for joint birthday parties. I struggled to even like my stepson most days and the ex wouldn’t even be in the same room with me, at least not respectfully.  I thought I was doing it wrong; I thought I was a terrible stepmom. ⁣
⁣
The truth is there’s no signature way to be a stepmom. There’s no one-size fits all because we’re all coming from different backgrounds and circumstances. We have to make space for the hard feelings, the confessions, the anger and the grief. ‘Cause forcing positivity and fitting into the “perfect family box” just isn’t in the cards sometimes.⁣ Once I was able to take the pressure off what I “should” be and “should” feel I was able to make room for what I authentically feel. I was able to create a unique and special relationship with my SS.
⁣
We can feel the pressures to BE something even more so around the holiday season… Remember you are perfect as you are. I’m sitting with  you through all the stepmom wins and heartaches. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Let’s talk about voice and FaceTime calls…📱⁣
⁣
Many are surprised to learn that we have never done calls or videos - neither has his mother. It’s always been this way and he knows no different. He’s never asked and we’ve only offered on a holiday. When he is with his parent, that’s their time. If there’s an emergency - the parents communicate. At least for now, he’s a 10yo boy who has no interest in talking on the phone; Perhaps this will change when he’s older and has his own device. But for now, I’m enjoying not having to hear BM’s voice in my home. 

Of course I want them to have a great relationship - but there’s a difference between fostering a relationship and disrespecting the child’s time with the parent they’re with….
⁣
This topic is oddly controversial so…How do you handle it? Do you have boundaries in place? What works/doesn’t work?⁣ 
⁣
⁣

We need the silver linings…we need the positive reframing to get us through, but…⁣
⁣
Sometimes it can also feel dismissive. ⁣
⁣
When I tell someone how much I care about my stepson, and the frustrations I have with our parenting dynamic I get responses like, “Wow, thank goodness he has you.” While my heart does burst and I do feel that I was brought to him for a reason - I’d rather our situation wasn’t so damn messy. ⁣
⁣
When I chat with stepmoms I always want them to walk away feeling more hopeful and encouraged. We need to celebrate the wins and be reminded of why we’re still here, that we add value and we’re important. However… I will always advocate for a stepmom to lean into the discomfort, and honor where they’re at right now. The hard feelings are telling you something and you can only move through them if you listen openly and resist the urge to “stay positive.”⁣
⁣
Sometimes we just need to hear, “Wow, that fucking sucks and you’re not alone.” ⁣

There’s a whole bag of emotions ….⁣
⁣
I hear from so many frustrated stepmoms who watch their partners deal with harassment and chaos, all because they don’t want to upset the ex or go back to court. It’s infuriating to watch our partners live in fear of losing their kids because they set a boundary with the ex or simply stand up for their rights as a parent. ⁣
⁣
It’s also extremely frustrating to watch our partners not parent the way they want to because they don’t want to upset their kids. The partners who won’t enforce chores, structure or consequences because they fear they’ll choose their mom and won’t come home anymore. As a stepmom who’s not the “preferred house” I know my husband picks and chooses what he enforces, hoping we’ll gain a few “cool points”. ⁣
⁣
This dynamic is hard for our partners. I have so much compassion for the position they’re in. I imagine it feels there’s no “right” choice. However, what I’ve seen in the years of coaching stepmoms is this: the health of the relationship is being threatened when our partners continue to accommodate the exes emotions and parenting through fear of upsetting the kids isn’t always sustainable or actually in the true best interest of the kids. ⁣
⁣
Sending love to all of you who have this dynamic. This shit isn’t easy, your feelings are valid, there are ways to navigate it and you aren’t alone. ⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

There are amazing stepmoms EVERYWHERE…⁣
⁣
If a stepmom posts about how she shows up for their stepkid there are two types of commenters. The ones who say “that’s nice but you’re not the mom” and those who say “you’re amazing! I wish all stepmoms were like you!” Both comments are wildly confused. But let’s focus on the second one…⁣
⁣
MOST stepmoms are amazing, thoughtful, loving, warm and kind. They don’t carry around poison apples, they aren’t trying to send the kids off to boarding school, they aren’t hateful and evil. They show up, give a shit and are trying to carve out space in their family. ⁣
⁣
But people see what they want to see and attach their own shit to our story. For whatever reason, people will assume the worst in us until proven otherwise. They think amazing stepmoms are an exception, not the rule. ⁣
⁣
So here are some comments I would drop on your stepmom post…⁣
“You’re an amazing stepmom”⁣
“I love how you show up for your family.”⁣
“I can see how much you care.” ⁣
“You are so valued and important.” ⁣
“Stepmoms are f*cking amazing and though I know it’s hard you’re killing it.” 😉⁣
⁣
What comments would you like to see? ⁣
How can we start responding to the wildly dumb ones? 😂⁣
⁣

Who needs a break??🙋🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣⁣
Whether it’s a break from your stepkids, a break from your partner or just a break from all the holiday stimulation… it’s okay. ⁣
⁣
Needing a break doesn’t mean you’re awful or mean or evil or not strong enough. It means you’re normal and human. It means you’re carrying a lot and you need to sit down and catch your breath. If your physical health was fatigued, wouldn’t you care for yourself? Your mental and emotional health needs your attention too. ⁣
⁣
Here’s your reminder and a little push…⁣
Make a break happen. Go see a friend. Schedule a date night. Sit alone in a dark and quiet room and do whatever fills your soul (Emily in Paris??🤪). You deserve it, mama. You really and truly do. ⁣
⁣
⁣

Nope, not a chance, can’t make me….🤣⁣
⁣
Before I get blasted in comments for being an evil,  negative stepmom, here me out. First…if this works for you - that’s GREAT! Go on those family vacays, make your tiktoks and do it all “for the kids”. Just don’t shame others for not doing the same. Everyone’s dynamic and comfort level is different and we shouldn’t be made to feel like failures. ⁣
⁣
Here’s the thing - even if the ex didn’t hate my guts and have an incessant commitment for conflict… I still wouldn’t want to be friends with her. Why? Because she’s my partner’s EX and that’s WEIRD to me.😐 The only reason why she’s in my life is because of my stepson and he doesn’t need to see us group hugging to have a childhood full of love. ⁣
⁣
Honor your comfort level. You’re not evil if you don’t want to be besties. And if those #blendedfamilygoals videos make you cringe, you’re not alone. 🥴⁣
⁣

Some people worry about their Alexa reporting their every move…Stepmoms worry about their stepkid. 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
I feel like I’m constantly being watched. It’s the obvious comments like, “My mom doesn’t do it that way.” ⁣But also my own internal insecurity...⁣“Will he tell his mom about this?” ⁣OR “We’ll get an email about this one.”🙄⁣
⁣⁣
My partner gets it…sort of, not really. He doesn’t carry the same emotional weight I do. He walks around with the privileged title of “Dad”, meanwhile I’m under a microscope with a target on my back. And the “just be yourself” advice does nothing for me. “Being my (awesome) self” is why she hates me. 😂 I’m sure you can relate…⁣
⁣
So how can we be comfortable in our homes? For me it’s remaining confident in who I am, and how my partner and I parent. Also, boundaries with the ex and honesty with my stepson. We say, “yup, your two homes are different” a lot.⁣
⁣
What helps you feel more at home and not in a fishbowl? ⁣

Big topic here…let’s unpack it. 😉⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We hear “disengagement” offered as a tool to use when we need to step back. Disengaging is tapping your partner into the game. It’s an act of self care. It’s reconnecting with what you WANT to do not want you feel you SHOULD do. Disengaging is a healthy way to focus on your mental health, your relationship and your family. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Disengaging is not selfish. It’s not coming from a place of apathy. When we choose to disengage it’s not to see your partner struggle without you. It’s not used to prove a point. Disengaging isn’t an opportunity to hold a grudge or build resentment. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Examples:⁣⁣
If you choose to disengage from communication with the ex - you must release the control and trust your partner to handle it. ⁣⁣
⁣
If you choose to disengage from enforcing discipline, you can’t hold resentment for not being involved (because you really want to).⁣
⁣⁣
If you’re contemplating disengaging ask yourself what feelings are contributing? What do you want to be feeling? Is disengaging the answer or is there something else? Acceptance? Redefining your role? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Disengaging is an amazing tool if used correctly. True freedom through disengaging comes from letting go and focusing on growth and happiness. It’s a recharge. If it’s leading to more negative feelings it’s time to reassess. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Who feels they disengaged? ⁣⁣
What’s been great about it - what’s been hard?⁣⁣
⁣
Want to chat more about this? Girl, let’s do it. ⁣
Schedule a 1:1!⁣
⁣⁣

Between the feelings and the behavior, there is the person…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I get a lot of shit for what I post. I share my feelings of frustration, annoyance, resentment… and I get comments or DMs assuming I’m this terrible monster of a stepmom. People assume that because I have these feelings I must be acting on them, “I feel sorry for your stepson”. What ignorance. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Feelings do not automatically dictate behavior, just as behavior can’t always explain what we’re feeling. Before acting on the feeling, there is free will, choice, conscious and impulse control to exercise before choosing a course of action; We may feel things, but it’s what we do with these feelings that matter. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
On this platform I share my struggles, but you don’t get the whole picture. You don’t see the hugs I get when my stepson walks in the door. You don’t see me wipe his tears away when his heart is hurting. You don’t see his smile when I make his favorite muffins or when I praise him for another awesome drawing. You don’t hear him say “I love you, mom.” as I style his hair. People hear me share about my anxiety of transition day and feel bad for him - not seeing the effort that goes in to making sure he feels comforted and welcomed home. Don’t feel sorry for my son. I am capable of processing my emotions and ensuring he gets the best parts of me.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Stepmoms are made to feel shitty for the feelings we have, which keeps us quiet and judging ourselves. ⁣
⁣⁣
But I see you: Between those hard feelings and the behavior is YOU. And YOU are amazing. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

To be fair… going above and beyond is kinda my nature. ⁣
⁣
So is being organized, on time, thoughtful and forgiving. Recovering people pleasers anywhere? 🙋🏻‍♀️Mix this with becoming a stepmom and I was destined to struggle with honoring my own damn boundaries and caring for my own mental health. ⁣
⁣
I often feel MORE pressure to show up and be awesome because I’m not his “real mom”. She can mess up or not show up and still get all the praise. I fumble because I’m human yet I don’t get the same grace. ⁣
⁣
I often feel I’m under a microscope and held to higher standards so I take the bait and show up, often more than the other two fully functioning parents. I have to check myself constantly…. ⁣
⁣
If my mental health and happiness is being threatened I pull back. I shouldn’t be working harder, worrying more or sacrificing it all. Even if it’s in my nature to step up…⁣
⁣

Would you watch it?! 🍿🍿🍿⁣
⁣
We need some accurate representation in the media. I want people to see what REAL stepmoms are like. I want cameras following stepmoms as they help with homework, show up to games, and email with teachers. I want people to see the truth and let go of the “evil” stigma. Let’s showcase our warmth, our commitment and our grit for navigating an ex who won’t quit. 😬⁣
⁣
Think we can get @bravotv on board? 😂⁣

In which case… we’re not welcome. 🙄⁣
⁣
Grandparents, aunts and uncles, best friends and even neighbors are welcomed into the “village” of raising kids. Okay, let’s be real - even stepdads are more praised than stepmoms. So why is this? ⁣
Here’s my theory: none of the above people threaten the role of “mother”. ⁣
⁣
Our existence must mean we’re overstepping and doing things only a mom should do. There just isn’t enough room for two. We can’t interfere. We aren’t “mom”. If we shine, it dims the light of the “real mom”. But other people in the village …. No problem. ⁣
⁣
Some examples of this double standard…⁣
A stepdad can help with homework and it’s him “stepping up”. An aunt can take her niece bra shopping, or help with hair and makeup. A friend can give advice and emotional support - but if a stepmom does any of these things …. We might get backlash, and “that’s not your place”…”what would the mom think?”….”how does SHE feel?” ⁣
⁣
It’s absurd, frustrating and damn exhausting. We have to change the narrative. We deserve to be seen as an asset - not a threat. We should be respected and appreciated for what we bring to the table. We have qualities to pass down to our kids. We have wisdom and love to contribute. We are important; we’re part of the village. ♥️⁣
⁣
⁣

Their disappointment is not your responsibility…⁣
⁣
They’re entitled to their feeling when you’ve established a boundary, spoke up or said “no”. But their response to your needs does not need to push you to feel guilty or bend to their requests. ⁣
⁣
I told my husband I wouldn’t be responsible for school pick-ups. I said I will no longer be reminding him about emails that need to be sent or appointments that need to be scheduled. I told him I won’t stay home every SS week and if I want to see my friends, I’ll be doing so. ⁣
⁣
Is this inconvenient for him? Sometimes. Is it different than what I’ve done in the past? Totally. Do I feel like I’m disappointing him and I’m not being the best wife, stepmom, parent ever? A little. But you know what’s more important to me? Being there for myself … not just who I am or what I provide for others. I matter, and I won’t feel guilty for that.⁣
⁣
Stepmom, you have a lot of love to give. You know how to do things - sometimes better then anyone else letsbehonest…but that’s doesn’t mean your happiness and mental health have to suffer because of it. Let them be disappointed; it’s okay. ⁣
⁣
I’d rather disappoint than resent. ⁣
Wouldn’t you? ⁣Who needed this reminder today? 
⁣⁣

Blended life impacts my marriage and I hate it…😒⁣
⁣
Whether it’s feeling misunderstood or unsupported in my role….the stress of a custody schedule, navigating the relationship with my stepson, parenting style differences, or the inevitable and unavoidable chaos from the ex… my husband and I have argued about it all. ⁣
⁣
Nothing makes me feel more disconnected from my partner than arguing about this stuff. Nothing makes me feel more resentful than thinking our marriage would be different if this blended dynamic didn't exist. What would it be like? I get sad thinking about how much happier we would be…⁣
⁣
Anyone else? ⁣
⁣
This is the grief I carry and I have to acknowledge it to move through it. This is my source of resentment, but I have to find acceptance that this is my reality. Because at the end of the day, I will choose my husband over and over again. My husband and I may have disagreements about blended family shit, but it’s on us to protect our marriage and home from the chaos. Daydreaming about a life I’ll never have prevents me from celebrating what we’ve created together. I HAVE to remember this…⁣
⁣
Who needs this reminder too? ⁣
How has your relationship been impacted by blended life? How has it made you stronger? ⁣

Ever wonder why you’re SO tired after your SKs leave...? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Ever hesitate communicating to your partner how tiring it is to be around their kid(s)? ‘Cause they just won’t get it...?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You’re right, they won’t. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Being a stepmom takes an extreme amount of mental and emotional energy. We are constantly self-assessing, self-correcting and questioning what we can, can’t, should or should not do. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐𝘴 𝘪𝘵 𝘰𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝘐 𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘪𝘮 𝘵𝘰 𝘤𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘯 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘳𝘰𝘰𝘮?” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐 𝘣𝘦𝘵 𝘩𝘦 𝘭𝘪𝘬𝘦𝘴 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘮’𝘴 𝘴𝘱𝘢𝘨𝘩𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘪 𝘣𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘳.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘞𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘮 𝘐 𝘵𝘶𝘤𝘬 𝘩𝘪𝘮 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘦𝘥?” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐’𝘮 𝘨𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘴𝘩𝘪𝘵 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴, 𝘐’𝘮 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s constant, and we’re not even aware we’re doing it. We’re always gauging the appropriateness, the relationship, the impact... sometimes it’s not even until they leave that we notice we haven’t taken a breath in days. We feel drained, depleted and yes...relieved.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Biological parents don’t operate at the same level we do, it’s unique and hard to explain so if you’re feeling shame for it - I’m here to normalize it. ⁣
⁣⁣
Next time you need to justify your exhaustion to your partner, or better yet, your need for a break...let them know it’s not their kid(s) that are necessarily running you ragged....it’s your mind you can’t turn off. ⁣⁣
⁣

Hanging on by a thread is just baseline now 🤪⁣
⁣
I had a pretty normal and healthy case of anxiety before becoming a stepmom. I had reasonable stressors, I was able to sleep well without a special gummy and I often said things like “meh, no worries.” Bahahahaha fast forward to 9 years of stepmotherhood…I’m full of worries and I have all the gray hair to prove it - though I dye it so you’ll just have to trust me.😉⁣
⁣
Becoming a stepmom has been one of my largest forms of stress. Whether it’s the identity shift, the change in responsibility, the toll it has in my marriage or the ex and all she brings to the table…I have loads to stress about. ⁣
⁣
Can you relate? Do you feel you used to be more “carefree” and now stressed and anxious is your new normal? ⁣
⁣
🧘🏻‍♀️ DEEP BREATHS….⁣
Normalize the reasons why. You have taken on a lot. This is unknown territory. You truly didn’t know what you were signing up for and SO MUCH is out of your control. Feeling stressed and anxious is a normal reaction to an obscene amount of change and/or bullshit. 😬⁣
⁣
Honor those feelings. Take time for yourself. Find what soothes your soul and do a lot of it. ⁣
Better yet… identify what is sucking your energy and stop doing it. ⁣
⁣
Instead of saying “yes” to everything start saying “thanks but no thanks”⁣
Instead of scrolling through the ex’s social media, pick up a book or catch up on your shows. Take ownership of what IS in your control. Some stress may never go away but it doesn’t need to become apart of us. ⁣
⁣
What’s stressing you out right now and what can you do to soothe it? ⁣
⁣⁣

Kids are annoying…that’s like, their thing. 😣⁣
⁣
My stepson makes weird noises when he eats. ⁣
He constantly talks about Pokémon or some video game and has zero social awareness to recognize no one is interested.⁣
His finger lives in his nose. ⁣
I have to remind him of everything at least 3 times….⁣
⁣
He’s 11. This is typical. My husband can get irritated with him. He can say things like “omg when is bedtime?” It’s normal for parents to be annoyed and express it freely. Can stepmoms? ⁣
⁣
It’s taken awhile but my husband has welcomed me into the world of embracing the suck together, as a team. We can both safely share what we’re annoyed by or frustrated with, free of shame and guilt. Nothing is sexier than your person creating space for you to just live in your feelings. 😍⁣
⁣
We’re parents too. We’re doing it. We’re exposed and not immune to all the annoying things kids can do. It doesn’t mean we hate the kids. It doesn’t mean we are calling our partners bad parents. ⁣It just means we’re in the club. 

Who’s ready for others to make space for us? 
⁣⁣⁣

You know who has the biggest critique of a stepmom??⁣
⁣
People who aren’t stepmoms. 😑⁣
⁣
I liken it to people watching the Olympics. An Olympic Athlete tumbles on the ice or misses a hit and some asshole on their couch yells, “C’mon! It’s not that hard!”⁣… Bitch, you get on the ice and do it - then we’ll talk. It ain’t easy!⁣
⁣
But even if we know our feelings and experiences are real, we’re vulnerable to their opinions aren’t we? We don’t want to be evil. We don’t always know what’s “right”. We wonder if we’re overreacting. We question ourselves…⁣
⁣
“Can I be a stepmom if I’m not married?” ⁣
“Am I awful because I don’t love my stepkid?”⁣
⁣
Questions like this are based on expectations placed on stepmoms. Expectations that we don’t have to conform to. I have this belief that stepmoms get to dictate how they show up in their relationships and homes - radical, right?⁣
There’s a million ways to be a stepmom and only the stepmom can decide what’s best for her and her family. Love your stepkid - or don’t. Be called “mom” - or don’t.  Be super involved - or don’t. ⁣
⁣
You do you, boo. ⁣

She’s their mom and she’s not going anywhere….⁣
⁣
But neither are we. ⁣
⁣
Stepmoms have no choice but to consider the ex - and by “consider” I don’t mean solely in the affectionate way. I mean we can’t disregard our partner’s past and the mother of their children. This comes with the territory and we’re forced to grapple with the feelings that accompany this role. So why can’t they accept that their exes have moved on and there’s another woman who they might have to interact with, or at the very least hear of? ⁣
⁣
It’s like they expected their exes to never move on and die alone. And while I never expected to be embraced or appreciated, I have expected the bare minimum of accepting that I exist. Silly me. Why is this so difficult??⁣
⁣
Have you wondered the same?⁣
⁣
While we would love to be accepted or considered in the slightest - we have to remind ourselves that they’re responsible for doing the work. They’re sadness, grief, bitterness, resentment etc. unfortunately keeps them from moving forward into acceptance and peace. Does it suck? Yes. Would you behave differently? Absolutely. But remember it has very little to do with you, and what she thinks of you is none of your business.⁣
⁣
She can disregard you all she wants - but look at you… still here and being awesome. 😘⁣

How dare you be happy and not think about how others might feel... 🙄⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
As stepmoms we’re always assessing how everyone is being impacted...even when it comes to our own happiness. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
💓You’re dating and decide to move in together ....how’s BM going to react? Will the kids be accepting? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
💍You’re engaged! Congratulations! Oh shit, how and when do you break the news to BM? The kids? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🤰🏻You’re pregnant! How exciting! How do you tell the kids? Do you tell them before BM? Is she going to freak the fuck out and make your pregnancy stressful? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣
And every joyous moment in between....⁣
⁣⁣Ladies...this shit is exhausting. And there’s no escaping it, really. When it comes to the kids...of course their experiences matter. But oh-my-god do I struggle considering another woman’s delicate feelings when all I want to do is live my one life with the person I love. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
So let’s make a promise to one another:⁣⁣⁣
Celebrate the joyous times...⁣⁣⁣
Focus on YOUR happiness...⁣⁣⁣
And never let them dim your light. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
You are deserving. ⁣⁣⁣

Who feels like they’re living multiple lives? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I recently shared in my stories the feelings I have when I shift from life with my husband and daughter, to life with my stepson. The shifts in my identity, responsibility and expectations are jolting and exhausting. I feel like I live two separate lives that fill me up and deplete me very differently. Sometimes it’s really manageable, just part of the routine. Other times I loathe and dread it. I’ve accepted that both responses are okay. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Whether you’re a full-time stepmom, multiple transitions a week, summer custody or something else... we’ve ALL felt the shift. The shift of life with just you and your partner, to life with the kid(s). The shift of comfort in your own home, to well... not as comfortable. The shift of having your partner’s attention, support and patience, to feeling a bit left out and misunderstood. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Some of the feelings we carry with these shifts are just part of the natural journey of being a stepmom. But that doesn’t mean we can’t lessen the negative impacts. We can’t LOSE ourself in this role. We deserve to feel happy and loved in all parts of our lives. We can feel the shift, but it doesn’t need to control us. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Take care of your true self, she needs you. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Sometimes I need to remember that it won’t always be this way…♥️⁣
⁣
We won’t always have the custody schedule guiding our lives. We won’t always have to communicate with the ex or feel her presence in our home. My stepson will grow up and our concerns will shift. I’m looking forward to the days when he’s coming to visit because he wants to. I want to hear about his mom’s choices and not feel the fear of how it will impact mine.⁣
⁣
I look to my husband’s stepmom for this reminder because seasoned stepmoms know…just because the kids are grown doesn’t mean stepmom life is over or “easy”. But damn I’ll be ready for the change in scenery because my current concerns are getting old and I’m tired. ⁣
⁣
I aim to validate my current feelings but remind myself that this is temporary. It’s soothing to focus on the future, but I don’t want to wish time away. It’s the conflict of staying present but hopeful for the day I’ll wake up with my husband and it will JUST be the stressors of OUR home.⁣
⁣
Be gentle with yourself now and know it won’t always be this way, mama. ⁣
⁣
Who needed this reminder? ⁣
⁣⁣

Oh you have a kid? Sweet… ill be like the cool aunt. The one who gets to hang out and watch cartoons. The one that I don’t know… doesn’t worry about all the parenting junk because there are already parents in the picture. Why did I think that was a thing? 😂⁣⁣

Because y’all seem a whole lot less anxious than we are 😂⁣
⁣
Managing high conflict is a whole other side of being a stepmom, and it’s hard when people don’t understand - or worse, think you’re overanalyzing, overreacting or overstepping. ⁣⁣
⁣
Whether it’s family, a friend or even another stepmom…Those who aren’t in it may not realize what managing high conflict can feel like…⁣
⁣
You’re always on edge. ⁣⁣
You’re always needing to defend your happiness. ⁣⁣
You always have to be 10 steps ahead. ⁣⁣
You have to document everything. ⁣⁣
Nothing is simple, everything turns into an event, an argument … CONFLICT.⁣
but history and trauma will tell us IT IS.⁣
⁣
Some blended family advice isn’t so simple  because you’re dealing with a bigger issue: Narcissism...abuse…instability...aggression⁣
...a toxic “co-parent”. ⁣A simple story of an ex trying to change the custody schedule may not seem like a big deal…but to a stepmom with HC… IT IS.⁣
⁣
And if you don’t know what any of this is like (yay!) hold compassion for the stepmom who’s doing her best in the mess. The last thing we need is judgement. 😘⁣

Love them like they’re your own, but don’t forget they’re not yours….⁣
⁣
Show up and be involved, but don’t make the ex look bad. Welcome them into your lives and heart, but keep a distance because they have a mom. Don’t treat them any different than you would your own child, but don’t forget they aren’t yours so your opinions, values and parenting styles don’t matter. ⁣
⁣
We can’t win, so I refuse to entertain this narrative. I refuse to live my life protecting the ego of the ex. You don’t like that I’m teaching him how to tie his shoes? You don’t like that we have our own inside jokes and he loves our dance parties? You don’t like that he goes to my family functions and is treated like my son… how dare I. Sorry, not sorry. Those things all benefit him and that’s a YOU problem. ⁣
⁣
I won’t give him less so the ex feels better about herself; just BE better. ⁣
⁣
They can’t have it both ways. Only YOU decide how you want to show up and it’s not your responsibility to be smaller and more digestible. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

I needed a pep talk and this is what I came up with…⁣
⁣
Stepmoms make sacrifices everyday to be with the person they love. Stepmoms are the most⁣
thoughtful and considerate group of women I’ve ever known or been apart of - despite what the media might portray. Stepmoms are constantly in positions of choosing what’s best for their partner, their stepkids or overall family, even at the sacrifice of what’s best for them. We carry complicated emotions but our main hope is our family will benefit - that we’ll see the reward. ⁣
⁣
My husband and I have been put in the position of possibly taking my stepson full-time. His mother is making decisions that wouldn’t allow a 50/50 schedule and we won’t entertain my SS being raised by her friends or a babysitter. If she can’t care for him, he should be with us. Is this better for me? My mental health? My sanity? Probably not - ya girl loves her weeks “off”… but it’s better for HIM. Therein lies the sacrifice. I can only hope the reward is his health, safety and happiness. ⁣
⁣
It’s not easy. We don’t always like it or even agree. Yet here we are showing up for our kids and family like any other mother should. ⁣
⁣
So if you needed this pep talk too…⁣
I’m sending you all love today and everyday. Even in the darkest season of sacrifice, I see you and I hope you find your light. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣
You are loved.⁣
You are valued.⁣
You matter. ⁣
⁣

And was it with soap?! 😝🧼⁣⁣

I hope my stepson looks back and knows I always had his back. I hope he knows I encouraged him to read every day because I care about his growing brain. I hope he knows that even though it was annoying and he didn’t want to try, I believed in him and knew he could do hard things. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
And honestly… I hope someday he sees I sometimes cared more than his other two parents… does that make me awful? ⁣

He doesn’t understand a lot of our dynamics as a blended family - I know he wishes things were different. I know he wishes his parents all lived together and he didn’t have two homes and holidays — regardless of how we try and sell it to him as a fun thing.⁣

I hope he looks back and sees a stepmom who was doing her best, and always tried to do what was best for him. ⁣

I was recently reminded that I’m MORE than a stepmom… so I’m reminding you…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In choosing to take on this role we’ve all experienced an identity shift. In that transition we’ve gained parts of ourselves and consequently have shed some of the parts we’ve enjoyed most.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When I find myself saying “I used to be so chill” or “I used to travel” …. It’s a sign to reassess. We all need breaks - and ALL moms need breaks to feel a little more themselves, not just what they do for others.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣In addition to parenting…we also have this added complexity of navigating an ex, the emotions of feeling like an outsider, not feeling in control of our own lives, grieving the life we won’t have and then feeling guilty for it...it gets HEAVY and we need to put it down.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A break could mean a date night. ⁣⁣♥️⁣
A break could mean a night alone to yourself - trash tv and a yummy spread is my go-to.⁣🍿⁣
A break could mean leaving on a transition day to hang out with friends - your partner can handle it, it’s okay. ✌🏽⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Whatever a break means to you..⁣.⁣⁣
Express it, make it happen...and don’t for a single second feel guilty about it. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You are worthy and so much more than a stepmom. So…What can you do this weekend to feel a little bit more like YOU?⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

⁣
Your hopes and dreams for your family require no explanation. The things that matter to you are worth talking about. Your feelings matter and deserve validation. Your boundaries and comfort level require respect. The way you want to show up in your family and in this stepmom role is yours to define and edit as you deem necessary. ⁣

Sometimes it feels no matter what we do, it’s never enough. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I’m well aware of this reality and it still cuts deep. Here’s the thing:⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I want my stepson’s mom to thrive. I want her to get her shit together, her priorities straight, put her big girl pants on and BE BETTER for him. But the truth is she continues to disappoint him, and still walks on water. ⁣Meanwhile, I know I can’t change her so I focus on what I can control: ME. ⁣
⁣
So…I’m there to cheer him on, plan the birthday parties, have the hard conversations, wipe the tears, buy the favorites, do the science projects, show up at school events and it’s just expected of me, no recognition needed? I do the hard stuff, and she swoops in for the praise and admiration. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Now, sure I could stop doing all of it. Disengage. He’s not my kid. But I WANT to be there for him. He deserves this type of love and hype. It’s not his fault and pulling away from him and not showing up as me is doing us both a disservice. I may not get all the praise and appreciation, but that can’t be my biggest motivator: he is. She hates me for this, but the irony is…if she would step the fuck up maybe I wouldn’t feel compelled to be so involved. 🙄⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I’m not overwhelmed, I’m not even resentful. She’s mom and she can do no wrong; I get it. ⁣⁣
Still doesn’t suck any less. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Who else feels this? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

If we can’t be met at this basic level…then there’s not much left to say…✌🏻⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Whether it’s a family member who dismisses your role because “you’re not the mom”, or a stranger on the internet who feels the need to say “well didn’t you sign up for this?” they clearly don’t get it, and it’s exhausting and hurtful  trying to explain. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Just like anything else, you don’t really know unless you’ve lived it. But it’s important to surround yourself with those who are supportive, despite not experiencing it themselves. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Don’t waste your energy defending your feelings, choices and family to someone who is committed to misunderstanding or judging. This may mean distancing yourself or even losing friendships - but so be it. Make room for those who are truly, authentically rooting for you. ♥️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
✨Swipe for bonus, babes. It’s a vibe. ✨⁣⁣

Resentment breeds in a lot of different ways…⁣
⁣
⁣
One of the biggest sources of resentment for me is when I’m doing things I truly don’t want to do, or I feel deeply taken advantage of. ⁣
⁣
In my early days of stepmotherhood I was saying “yes” to everything because I felt like I should. I felt I had to prove myself. I needed to show my then boyfriend that I was great with kids, a “mom” type, that I was the dream girl he’d been searching for. 💁🏻‍♀️ I mean, I am that girl but like, I didn’t have to lose myself in the process. I also felt the need to show the ex that I was a good person, kind and thoughtful. That I was worthy of respect and understanding… hahhahaha oh silly, optimistic me. ⁣😂
⁣
Burnout and resentment eventually found me and I had to assess how I was choosing to show up. I had to let go of the internal pressure and really advocate for what I wanted from the relationship - not just how I could contribute. ⁣I had to start saying “thank you, but no” and realize that now matter how awesome I am the ex does not care. If I was going to be in this for the long haul - I had to start showing up for me, not for acceptance. 
⁣
When we find ourselves feeling resentful it’s a signal to look inward and assess how we’ve contributed and where we need to adjust. ⁣
In a role where it’s easy to lose yourself we have to be intentional about remaining authentic to our wants and needs; it’s our damn lifeline. ⁣
⁣
Any of this resonating? Who needs to reassess? ⁣

Nope, not real. Just pretending…🙄🤦🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s 2023 and somehow we’re still in a world that believes a child must exit your uterus for you to enter the community of motherhood. FFS.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I remember when I my stepson was 3yo…I took him to the park while my then boyfriend was working. I stood with other moms as we watched the kids climb and slide. I felt part of the club as we talked potty training, picky eaters and being a “threenager”. Their conversation shifted to postpartum, sleepless nights and breast or bottle. I got quiet. This experience was the first of many where I FELT like I was a mom but was quickly slapped with doubt…was I just pretending? Am I an imposter? If I didn’t “earn my stripes” can I still be recognized for how I show up now? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It took me a few years to really feel confident but the answer is YES. We may not have birthed them, but everything we do for them now fucking counts and it matters. I haven’t said it in awhile so here it is: Mom is a Verb. It’s in our actions, not our biology that makes us part of the club and I’m tired of society minimizing our role.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We’re in it. We’re doing it. Show up to those parks or sports events and stand with the other moms with your head held high. 👑If they question you, see it as an opportunity to educate them on what “real stepmoms” are. ‘Cause we’re badass and can’t be messed with. 😉⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When have you felt “less than” among other moms? How have your feelings evolved? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣

It’s not co-parenting if she’s only trying to “win”….⁣
⁣
How many of you were sold the idea that your partner and their ex got along just fine, only to observe later that it’s because she treats them like a doormat and your partner is afraid to upset her? Or worse, afraid of her retaliation using the kids? ⁣
⁣
It’s a cycle we didn’t see until we were in it… ⁣
our partners continue to accommodate the unreasonable ex because they’ve always been the accommodater and because high-conflict exes can't differentiate their needs from those of their kids, they will to anything to hurt the other parent and "win." The ex gets aggressive or threatening, our partners get scared and abandon their goals, the ex gets what she wants and the illusion of healthy coparenting lives on. Sound familiar?⁣
⁣
If this resonates I imagine you’re pretty damn frustrated. Not only were you fooled with the smoke and mirrors, but you’re tired of your partner being manipulated and want so badly for them to stand up for themselves, for your stepkids, for you….⁣
⁣
So now what? Recognizing the dynamic is the first step - call it what it is. If it’s dysfunctional, one-sided and lacking respect… it’s not co-parenting. Know that this power dynamic has been established well before you came into the picture and it’s complicated to unravel. Know that you can’t force your partner to step up and change anything until they’ve gained their own awareness and motivation for change. Maybe they need healing. Maybe they need validation and reassurance. The solutions and boundaries might be obvious to you, but be gentle with your partner as they figure out how to move forward. ⁣
⁣
You can’t control anything but your own involvement and reaction. Above all else, be gentle with yourself and establish the boundaries you need for happiness and safety.⁣
⁣

A big ass crazy zoo… 😵‍💫
⁣
We all made a choice, right? The moment we learned our partner’s had a kid (or plural) we could have said, “yea, not for me.” But we didn’t. Our hearts wanted the person in front of us, or at least our minds wanted to give it a shot. ⁣
⁣
I wasn’t looking for a family when I met my partner. I was barely looking for a boyfriend. 😂 But I got swept away and as shit started getting real I continued to make that decision over and over again: “Is this for me? Can I do it?” I love my husband and he is what I always come back to. ⁣
⁣
As stepmoms, we are in the position of having to manage some really hard shit in order to be with the one we love…and frankly, it sucks sometimes. People who say “it’s a package deal” aren’t wrong. But they’re ignorantly simplifying our experience. ⁣
⁣
We stumbled upon someone wonderful and got a whole lot more than we bargained for…⁣

amiright?! 🐨

Okay…so hear me out…😬⁣
⁣
I fell in love and became a stepparent by proxy. I in no way was looking to take on diapers, tantrums and a custody schedule. ⁣
I took on all those things because I wanted to be with my partner and he just so happened to come with a cute-little-sticky-fingered three year old. The relationship I have with my husband will always be the priority - yes, even over the kids. ⁣
⁣
There is this assumption that just because children are already present - all romance goes out the window. Ummm, no. Just because I’m a stepmom doesn’t mean I want to sacrifice my date nights and kid-free vacations.⁣
⁣
Stepmoms don’t get the life-before-kids-experience. We’re just expected to plop right into family mode and not have any yearning for what “traditional” couples have. We are labeled selfish if we want time away from the kids. We’re told “you knew what you signed up for” (we didn’t) when we grieve the experiences we’ll never have. ⁣
⁣
Nope. I won’t have it. ⁣
Stepmoms….⁣
Advocate for the life you want and deserve. ⁣
I believe you can have it all. ⁣
You can be a stepmom, AND get date nights with your person. You can be a stepmom AND have romantic kid-free vacations. You can be a stepmom AND make your relationship a priority. ⁣
⁣
If your partner struggles with this - ask them⁣
what’s holding them back. Is it guilt? Do they have unsaid expectations? Do they just need to hear your needs communicated differently? ⁣
⁣
You are a partner first and a stepmom second…. Radical, I know. 😘⁣
⁣

I’m not evil….but I am human. ♥️⁣
⁣
It all just gets to be too much sometimes. Whether it’s the ex making decisions that impact our home, my partner getting frustrated and stressed, or direct attacks on me… it’s hard to show up for my stepson with energy and a smile. I know that’s what he deserves and damn do I try… but it’s tiring, you know? ⁣
⁣
Sometimes our stepkids embody their other parent. They talk like them, look like them (my case) and are sometimes even disrespectful like them and it feels like the ex is living in your home too. It can feel confusing and even unsafe at times. ⁣
⁣
“They’re just kids” is often the reminder. As if that’s supposed to wash away all these feelings. Yes. They ARE just kids and it’s our responsibility to process and do our own inner work so we can show up for them, shield them from what isn’t theirs to carry - but sometimes I just want to sit in the suck for a moment and be acknowledged that THIS is not how I want to be spending my energy.⁣
⁣
If this resonates… you’re not alone and I invite you to sit with me and give yourself some grace. The fact that this is difficult for you makes you a good stepmom; it makes you human. We have to first honor our feelings so we can tend to them in the way we deserve. The way our family deserves. ⁣
⁣
I see you, stepmom. ⁣
I am you. ⁣
⁣

This double standard keeps us feeling isolated and alone. ⁣
⁣
We see the posts, reels and tiktoks documenting a mother’s journey. The overwhelming times, the joyful times, the exhausted and frustrated times. Their village wraps them in “this is just a season” and “you’ll miss this” and “you’re doing great!”. ⁣
⁣
Take a peek at a stepmom sharing her struggles and comments read “you shouldn’t have been with someone with a kid”. Outside of social media we may share with our friends and family and we hear “maybe you’re not cut out for this” or “wow. Sounds like you hate the kids”. ⁣
⁣
I’ve pointed out this double standard before - and I’ll continue to remind you: you are deserving of the support mothers receive as you are also mothering. A bad day doesn’t mean a bad life and you deserve to have safe and comforting affirmations too. Just because you struggle doesn’t mean you need to question it all.⁣

Being a stepmom has been the most confusing role I’ve ever held….⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Among all the struggles, the relationship with my stepson has been one of my biggest sources of confusion. Am I connecting enough? Am I parenting too much? Is he comparing me to his mom? Am I the one comparing? How am I showing up and is it aligned with how I truly want to show up? How will he talk about me when he’s older? “My stepmom was…”⁣⁣⁣
I carry these thoughts with me always…and it’s exhausting. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I know I need to be more gentle with myself. The way I show up is enough. It may not be easy and it’s not always from a place of innate love…but he sees what I do everyday. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Stepmoms, my message to you is this: ⁣⁣⁣
Our stepkids have made an impact on our hearts, and us on theirs. It may not be biological or even love, but it matters and it’s special all on its own. Notice the small moments and let it quiet your anxieties and worries. Store it away for a rainy day. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Without a doubt, stepmom … you are making an impact just by being you. 🌹⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣

Make it make sense…⁣😵‍💫
⁣
Before I share my thoughts let me acknowledge how complex and convoluted this topic can be. ⁣
Starting with how society views fathers in general: you see a guy carting his kids around the store alone and he’s dad of the year 🏆 while a mom does that daily and gets “wow you have your hands full.” Mothers and fathers are viewed differently and stepparents are not immune. ⁣
⁣
Stepdads step up. They’re the bonus. How amazing for them to love kids they didn’t create out of the kindness of their heart. Stepmoms do it and we’re a threat and we need to stay in our lane. 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
The hypocrisy, y’all.⁣
So.. let’s talk about it. What’s been your experience? Is there a stepdad for your stepkids - how is he welcomed (or not) into the blended bunch? ⁣
⁣⁣

It’s hard to feel deeply misunderstood…⁣
⁣
I know I’m a good person. I know that I’m not looking to replace anyone; I’m just a chick who fell in love and has spent the last nine years carving out a place in my family. I know my intention are good, but I also know despite my best efforts to offer peace, she’ll never see me as an asset.⁣
⁣
Yet regardless of how she treats me, I want her happy. I want her to have a great relationship with my stepson. I want her to be successful and fulfill dreams. If she’s happy and successful, my stepson will feel it. I truly want what’s best for her .. woman to woman. Mom to mom. I’m never going to be the person she thinks I am, and she’ll never give me the opportunity to prove her otherwise. ⁣
⁣
….Sometimes being the bigger person really just sucks, doesn’t it?⁣
⁣
And yes… those are bananas 🍌🤣⁣
⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

The more we learn about ourselves in this role, the more we need to edit what no longer works for us...⁣
⁣
Like all of you - I didn’t know what I was getting myself into. ⁣
Like many of you - I jumped right into a parenting role and got way in over my head. ⁣
I had little to no boundaries, and my expectations were naive. I didn’t know what I was “allowed” to speak up about. I didn’t know where I fit. So I went along with everything, I was always trying to prove myself...and it worked, until it didn’t. ⁣
⁣
Anxiety. Depression. Resentment. Anger. Hopelessness.... you get the idea. By the time I was carrying all that negativity, my partner had gotten real comfortable with me being so “cool” and “go-with-the-flow”. Whoops. My mistake. ⁣
⁣
I needed to edit how I was showing up for him and my SS. I needed to voice my boundaries and expectations. I needed to show that I wasn’t just a casual addition to their already established family...I needed to be part of forming a new family. I needed to redefine what being a stepmom meant to ME, and not just embody what was assumed of me. ⁣
⁣
We can’t be held to who we were before we knew who we are (oh the things I would tell the young stepmom me😂). We have to be given the space to edit what is no longer serving us. ⁣
⁣
How have you changed from when you first took on this role? What have you had to edit?⁣

My DMs are telling me many of you need this reminder ♥️⁣
⁣
Let’s normalize this feeling, and not bring others down for expressing it. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Some days you just want to wash it all away. Some days you don’t want to take care of the kids (all moms feel this way sometimes, btw). Some days you don’t want to have to think about the ex, what’s she doing or not doing. Some days the weight of this role is too damn much. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
All you want is to feel some relief, freedom, peace....ONE moment to just live in love with your partner without all the SHIT. In case you need to hear it: those feelings are completely fucking warranted. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So if you’re not wanting to be a stepmom today...say it out loud. Own it. Give yourself some grace. Turn to another mama who is feeling the same way (I promise you, there are many) and let’s support each other. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We’re going to find our way, together. ⁣⁣

Communicating a boundary is hard, maintaining it is harder...⁣
⁣
A few important things to remember about establishing boundaries:⁣
1) Having a defined consequence is key and⁣
2) Resistance is normal. Whoever was benefiting from a lack of boundary is not going to be super excited about one being set. ⁣
⁣
So when you’re wondering why your boundary isn’t working or being respected, ask yourself if you’ve established a consequence and remain consistent with your needs. Don’t allow shame, guilt or “maybe it’s not a big deal.” to take over. ⁣
⁣
Don’t minimize your boundaries because they’ve made others uncomfortable. Your happiness depends on it. ⁣
⁣
What’s a boundary are you always maintaining? ⁣

It sucks having to consider everyone else in your happy moments. ⁣⁣🫠
⁣⁣
Typical, traditional, nuclear (whatever you want to call it) couples don’t have to wonder if an ex is going to try and sabotage their wedding. I have to explain why we don’t always bring my stepson on vacations. I’ve spoken to hundreds of stepmoms who want to take photos with just their ours baby and not be scrutinized. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“Simple” decisions aren’t simple when you’re a stepmom. We often analyze every little dynamic and every person’s emotion, consequently driving ourselves crazy and into a pit of resentment. Why can’t it just be easy?! 😩⁣⁣
⁣⁣
While we can’t dismiss everyone, we can work to feel more in control of our lives. We can talk to our partners about this pressure and frustration and establish understanding. We can decide whose opinions aren’t worth our energy. We can grow more confident in our choices, our needs and how we want to live our blended lives.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The “you’ll be judged regardless” mentality was created by stepmoms. So go on that vacation, plan the epic wedding and take all the photos. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Your life and your wants and needs matter. ⁣⁣
Don’t forget it. 😘⁣⁣
⁣⁣

And wondering why it’s all on you in the first place? 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
The other day my partner and I had a…moment. I came home later than usual with bags of groceries, and an impressive Target haul. I was tired and overstimulated. My husband greets me with a kiss and says, “we’re out of ketchup.” ⁣
⁣
WHAT THE ACTUAL EFF.⁣
⁣
My response was more of an eruption…🌋 ⁣
You see I just got home from grocery shopping, which means I have also planned the meals and taken inventory of all our needs. How could I have missed ketchup? Additionally I was out buying gifts and party supplies for my stepson’s birthday. “We’re out of ketchup” wasn’t about the ketchup. It was a simple comment that made me feel like everything is on me to remember, plan and execute. I felt unappreciated and immediately wanted to just say ✌🏽to it all. ⁣
⁣
Who else is the keeper of all the things? The  calendar manager and planner? Who else loses sleep because they’re thinking of an email that needs to be written or a uniform that needs to be washed? Who else stares at their partner while they sleep peacefully, wondering what it would be like to have a personal assistant, meal planner and cleaner? 🫠⁣
⁣
We carry a lot and this family/relationship dynamic is not specific to stepmoms. Woman and mothers all over are being told they’re overreacting or too controlling when really we would LOVE some balance and equity in the invisible, but very vital load we carry. ⁣
⁣
So I see you. And I hope you can have conversations with your partner to feel understood and more supported. My husband knows now what I need in those moments and I’ve communicated what I need moving forward….growth. ⁣
⁣
Oh… and for the record. We weren’t out of ketchup. 😂🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

It’s a lot easier to blame us, than to look in the mirror.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We’re always the villain. We’re always the reason for the conflict and chaos. If only we didn’t fall in love. If only the kids didn’t like us. If only we didn’t give a shit. How dare we want to have a happy home and family. But we’re screwed either way. If we weren’t committed and loving, she’d be mad at that too. 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s not about the stepmom. It’s about the ex’s unresolved emotions. Her grief. Her loss. Her resentment. Her insecurities. Knowing this does 3 things: ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
1) It makes space for compassion and empathy. Yea, I know it’s fucking hard. Especially when she’s a nightmare. But...woman to woman...we can put ourselves in her shoes and though we KNOW we’d handle it differently, we can appreciate the struggle. Also, ⁣⁣
2) It releases us from taking shit so personal. She’s going to be mad at whoever is standing next to her ex, caring for her kids. You’ve done nothing to deserve what she’s been dishing out - that’s all on her. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣3) It makes us reflect on our own high conflict tendencies - yes we have them. When she goes low, we have an opportunity to check ourselves and make sure we aren’t contributing. If you aren’t - 👏🏼then you can brush it off as a HER problem, not a YOU problem. ⁣
⁣
Now… swipe for a bonus. 😘⁣
⁣
⁣

And she knows it…⁣ 
⁣
This might be the stepmom reality I hate the most…⁣
⁣
The fact that SHE has the power to impact my relationship with my stepson. Her actions, her words, her acceptance or dismissal of me impacts the way my stepson sees me. It impacts the way he feels comfortable in our home, in our relationship. Regardless of how much effort I put into caring for him, investing in us… it could be ripped away with a simple comment from his mother. ⁣
⁣
I wish they would use their power for good and not evil. I wish they could tend to their own bruised egos and find confidence in their role as  mother. I wish they could see stepmoms as an asset and part of their village. I wish they could see that their child so badly needs them to accept the stepmom so they can feel at ease to love and live freely. It’s not one or the other…⁣
⁣
To the stepmoms putting in all the work, love and effort despite the ex’s goal to destroy it - I see you. It can feel hopeless at times, but know your stepkids need your care and consistency even when it’s hard. Even when you feel vulnerable. ⁣
⁣
I’m fueled by the hope that my stepson will see the truth - that he has a stepmom who adores and loves him. ⁣
⁣
Let hope fuel you too. ⁣

You are so much more than a stepmom...♥️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In chatting with so many of you I know how common it is to just dive right into this role. I did it. I was so hopeful, excited, in love and blindly naïve. I was taken over by this new relationship and idea of a family. But after awhile, the excitement became anxiety and the love was turning into resentment. Honestly it took a mini breakdown for me to realize that it was all my own doing. I had been neglecting myself. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We have to commit to caring for the woman we were before becoming a stepmom. The woman we were before needs us to fight for her, remember her and give her space to breathe and continue growing. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
If you were looking for a sign to take time for you, to communicate what you need to your partner... to schedule that class or plan that girls trip - this is it. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Don’t abandon yourself in an attempt to blend your family. You are so much more than the stepmom, the wife, the girlfriend, the chauffeur, the cook, the schedule keeper...⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So tell me something about yourself - who are you other than a stepmom? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣
I’ll go first: I’m Christina, an introvert with extrovert tendencies. I love rain, chocolate covered almonds and smelling books. I have always loved helping people. I’m a licensed skydiver, but I have a fear of heights - weird right?? I have a small circle of friends who I honestly feel are my soul mates…⁣
⁣
Now you go…⁣

Normalize NOT asking women when they’re having kids, especially stepmoms. ⁣
⁣
Maybe it’s just me, but the phrase “child of your own” just doesn’t feel right to me. It feels dismissive of the child(ren) you’re helping raise. It feels like you’re not enough of a mom unless you pushed someone out of your body. It implies that you’re not fulfilled or whole, like you’re just playing house until your “real” child comes along. I hated it before having my daughter - and I hate it now. ⁣
⁣
The decision to bring life into this world is between you and your partner - period. People may ask out of well-intended curiosity, but the answer is almost never easy. Financial stress, fertility, age, you just don’t want to…. All real and valid reasons. ⁣
⁣
To the stepmoms who are child-free hoping to grow their family - I see you. I hope that ache in your heart is soothed and until then, know the love and devotion you’re giving to your stepkid(s) is valued and important. To the stepmoms who are child-free by choice - I see you. I hope society’s expectations of women can take a seat so you have the freedom to love and be loved by your family - you’re perfect as you are. ⁣
⁣
You don’t need “one of your own” to be a mom. ⁣
Mom is a verb. ⁣
⁣

“No” is a complete sentence…🚫⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
As an Enneagram Type 2… I LOVE to be helpful, needed and accommodating. But as a stepmom, I have had to learn boundaries, letting go of guilt and get real comfortable saying “no.” If I don’t keep a pulse on this, I get burnt out and resentment builds. Big bummer, ladies 👎🏻⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
So what does this look like? Well…⁣⁣⁣
Have you ever agreed to do drop off, or take the kids to practice when you really didn’t want to - but you did it any way because it was more convenient (for someone else)? Have you ever agreed to stay with your SK while your partner works/has plans just because you didn’t have anything else going on? Do you often find yourself letting your true feelings slide because you don’t want to be a nag, start a fight or inconvenience anyone? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Now, I’m not saying go rouge and drop the partnership/teammate mentality. There’s always going to be a need for compromise and sacrifice BUT…We have to stop giving so much of ourselves that we lose our will to love; saying “yes” and always being available is not sustainable. You deserve to have your “free time” even if that means eating popcorn in bed while watching Real Housewives. You deserve to say “no” to recharge and protect your mental health. Go ahead and inconvenience someone; your peace is a priority. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
When was the last time you said “yes” when you didn’t really want to? When was the last time you said “no” and felt free?⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣

We’re all just winging it and deserve some grace…⁣
⁣
There’s no handbook in motherhood. There’s no “right” way to do it all. When I scroll social media I see a fortunate shift in the support for mothers. I see encouraging messages like “it’s okay if you don’t have it figured out” or “you did your best and your best is enough.” I want these messages for stepmoms too, because we are doing our best and it’s amazing. ⁣
⁣
Guess that’s why I’m here…💜⁣
⁣
To remind you that we’re in the parenting world together. To remind you that there’s no stepmom handbook and while there’s a growing source of guidance and “best practices” only YOU know what’s best for you and your family. We’re all just winging it because parenting is hard…and step parenting is complicated. ⁣
⁣
Imagine if all the exes, bio moms, and other parents could welcome us as part of the club. To give us grace and encouragement when we may not know what we’re doing. To see us in our humanness. ⁣
⁣
I see you stepmoms. ⁣
And you deserve all the accolades motherhood has to give because you’re doing it too. ⁣

A few years ago my husband said something pretty powerful…⁣
⁣
After one of my “why doesn’t she just give me a chance - I’m not a terrible person!!” rants, he looks me dead in the eye and said, “Babe, that’s what she’s afraid of.” He went on to say that it was probably easier for her to make me a monster in her head, and if she actually got to know me she would humanize me… maybe even LIKE me. 😱The horror! ⁣
⁣
This concept released me. Released me from the burden of trying to gain her approval. Released me from constantly wondering what I’ve done wrong or what I’ve done to deserve this - nothing and oh, nothing. He was right. If she got to know me, heard me out, saw me as a loving person in my SS’s life or even a loving person to my husband - well, she couldn’t handle it. I’m the villain in her story - and she’s committed to that narrative.⁣
⁣
I know it sucks to feel misunderstood and hated. I know you’re frustrated because you want to share your side of the story. I know you’re ruminating - knowing you would never behave like her. I get it…but I truly feel they’re choosing to see what they want to see, so nothing you do will change that. Only they can decide to change and I’m not holding my breath for that… are you? 😮‍💨⁣
⁣
Keep being amazing.💁🏻‍♀️⁣
Keep showing up and rocking it. 😎⁣
Keep your head high.👑⁣
Haters gonna hate.😘⁣

One of the most common misconceptions about being a stepmom…⁣
⁣
No, actually I don’t want to be MOM. ⁣
⁣
What I am trying to do is be a STEPMOM and apparently that means a bunch of different things to everyone. Step up. Be a bonus. Be present. Love them like your own. But don’t love them too much because remember, you’re not the mom. Grocery shop, cook meals, pack lunches, help with homework, bath time, show up to events, plan birthday parties, make holidays magical, carry the emotional load of a family… but also don’t do any of that because you’re not a parent. But do some of it because you can’t be lazy and evil. Do some of it, but don’t do it like me or better than me… but also do it exactly like me because I am always right. ⁣
⁣
Seriously… WTF do you want from us?⁣
⁣
The expectations are endless and constantly changing. We literally can’t win when our existence is based on the fluctuating ego strength of other people. Moms who feel the stepmom is “overstepping” need to take a look inward and ask themselves, “Is she overstepping or am I feeling insecure?” also throw in a “is my child benefiting from another loving, supportive person in their life?”. ⁣
⁣
We can have compassion for the ex and understand that her role is hard too, but she’s responsible for her own inner work and that doesn’t include dictating what you do in your family: This isn’t Build A Bitch.🤪 WE get to decide how we want to show up in this role. We get to decide what we’re comfortable with and how we want to support our partners and their kids.⁣
⁣
To the exes: Don’t get it twisted - we know who MOM is. There’s room for both of us if you choose to accept it. 😘⁣
⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
