Who’s been told they’re “overstepping”? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Whether it’s from the ex, a family member or a stranger on the internet.. people love to tell stepmoms where they should stand. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
While I absolutely agree there’s instances when the stepparent “should” step back and sometimes yes, even stepmoms can be high conflict and be involved for the “wrong” reasons (that’s a whole separate post). I do believe that’s a decision to be made between the stepparent, their partner and the comfort of the kids. I also believe it’s not all black and white and families and relationships evolve. For example:⁣⁣
⁣⁣
- most resources say I shouldn’t be involved in discipline. That I should leave it to my husband as the biological parent. Well…my husband wants me to be involved and respects me as an equal parent. He also wants my SS to see me that way. Did I jump right into discipline? No. I of course had to build a relationship first. But was the goal always for me to “step up”. Yup. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
- some resources say I shouldn’t do activities that a mother would do… like attend his MD appointments or take him shopping. I shouldn’t be helping him with homework or plan sleepovers. All of this seems absurd to me because these are the same people telling me to treat him “like my own” so the conflicting advice is laughable. 🙄⁣⁣
⁣⁣
- most resources say he shouldn’t call me “mom”. I’ve been in his life since he was 3yo. He doesn’t know a time before me. He knows I’m not his mother, but our relationship is special and full of love. This is the word he chose for me and I won’t dismiss him or our relationship. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
If I relied on all the “resources” out there I would be a confused and shameful mess. If you compare me to what they say is “the right way” I will always be told I overstep and I’m “too involved”. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I encourage you to seek out the resources that have good intentions but hold them up to your life and ask “does this fit for me and MY family?” because no walks the life you do and only you can define where you stand. ⁣⁣
⁣🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Release yourself of this...you got nothing to prove. ⁣
⁣
It’s not your responsibility to gain her acceptance. ⁣It is not your sole purpose to jump through her hoops and gain her approval. Come as you are, and let her work through her issues, ‘cause you could be the sweetest peach and she could still hate peaches. It’s not about you, babe. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Be yourself, be confident in who you are, how you show up and what you provide. Lean on your partner and know that her disapproval or lack of acceptance does not limit your love or commitment. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You may never be accepted, but you don’t need her permission to live the life you want...remember that. ⁣⁣
⁣

I haven’t done a post like this in awhile - and I’m saying this with nothing but love… ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Shaming, criticism and judgement is not welcome here. Stepmoms feel enough negativity from others, we don’t need it from each other. You will not relate to every stepmom emotion. You will not agree with everything I post. You may read a comment and have your own contrasting opinion - great! 🤩That’s the beauty of diversity and what also adds to the complexity of this experience; we’re not all the same. Let’s see these differences as an opportunity to bring us together and hold compassion, not create more division and shame. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Here is the expected etiquette when navigating this platform: ⁣⁣
✨ First and foremost, you choose to follow and engage. If it’s not for you - you may leave at any time and I don’t need a goodbye. I sincerely hope you find support that fits your needs. ♥️⁣⁣
✨I welcome you to share your stories and perspectives so long as they remain respectful - no name calling, no shaming, no judgement. ⁣⁣
✨If you can’t offer kindness, validation, compassion or encouragement then consider what you ARE trying to convey. If it’s simply to state your criticism or that you disagree - maybe rethink/edit your contribution. ⁣⁣
✨Lastly, quick reminder: there’s a person behind this page. I have my own story, feelings and threshold for bullshit. Don’t tear down the stepmoms that come here for support or come at me for not meeting your needs. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I work hard to create a safe space for stepmoms, and it truly saddens me when we turn on each other. A simple, “Damn, I don’t experience that personally but that must be hard.” can go a long way. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Thank you to all of you who vulnerably share your story while providing support and kindness to others. You make this the radical space what it is and I love you for it. 😘⁣⁣
⁣⁣
✨Now go on and keep being amazing, stepmom. ✨⁣⁣
⁣⁣

It’s hard not to compare, and your feelings are valid…♥️⁣
⁣
The holidays add an extra layer, right? Who else is feeling a little bitter about the extra shit we have to carry? The “childless” stepmoms who are sick of seeing baby announcements and so badly want their own bundle at Christmas…The stepmoms who are dealing with alienation and another holiday where their partner is sad and missing their kids…The stepmoms who feel like outsiders and just want the holidays to be over…⁣
⁣
As stepmoms we deal with issues other families may not even be aware of and it’s hard to not feel resentful and even jealous.⁣
With that said, while I’ll never “silver lining” your very really feelings, I will encourage you to be gentle with yourself, find the good and try not to invite the comparison in as it doesn’t serve you or your family. ⁣
⁣
To all the stepmoms who are battling their unique and difficult feelings - I see you. To those who are embracing the differences and celebrating the joys of their little blended family - I see you too. ⁣
⁣
What comparison can you let go of today - what piece of gratitude can replace it? ⁣
⁣⁣

We’re predisposed to being disliked simply because of what we represent…⁣
⁣
A stepmom represents:⁣
The relationship that didn’t work out. ⁣
Their ex has moved on.⁣
There’s another woman around the child(ren) they created together. ⁣
Their lives didn’t go the way they thought it would.⁣
⁣
You’re standing where she once stood. Loving on the person she either hates, or still holds affection for. You’re there with her children when she can’t be. ⁣
⁣
It makes sense; That would be hard. Seriously. I can hold this compassion for all the exes. It would be real easy to dislike the woman if I’m still moving through the emotions of loss, grief…resentment. But it’s what you do with those emotions that matter, right? It’s the ability to separate your own emotions from your role as a mom and your role as the ex and the line gets pretty damn blurry. ⁣
⁣
So when you’re taking things personal, wondering why she can’t accept you or why she can’t even acknowledge you… keep this in mind. It’s really not about YOU. And if it’s not about you, there’s really not much you can do about it. It’s HER journey. It’s the work she needs to do. ⁣
⁣
Stepmoms are set up to fail before we even begin. It fucking sucks, but release yourself of the notion that it’s your responsibility to make shit picture perfect. Show up as your most amazing self, and leave her to figure it out. ⁣
⁣⁣

Like… freakin’ wild…😳⁣
⁣⁣
Feeling uncomfortable in our home is hard to navigate. Our home is supposed to be our safe space, away from the chaos of the world. But when you’re a stepmom... it’s common to feel like you always have to be “on”. You’re hyper aware of what you say and do because there’s a reporter watching, not to mention all the invisible boundaries, expectations and lack of control. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Some of that discomfort never really goes away, but it can be lessened. Talk to your partner about having a “safe space” in your home. Talk about those expectations and explore what may help you feel more in control and less on guard.⁣ You deserve to feel comfortable. ⁣
⁣

Anyone else feel a bit conflicted...? 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
My husband had a dream. He wanted the stepmother to his child to just morph into this motherly figure and make up for the deficits of his ex. For this reason, he’s always been supportive and encouraging, especially in front of BM. I’ve appreciated him cheering me on, but it’s left me anxious to talk to him about certain feelings...what if I don’t want to be so involved? What if I don’t feel that motherly role? ⁣
⁣
Since day one BM has taken every opportunity to remind me I’m not his mother...(duh 🙄). She doesn’t want me involved. She doesn’t want my opinion as it “doesn’t concern you.” ...my favorite is... “know your role.” ⁣
⁣
But...What the hell is my role? ⁣
Disengaging feels damn good sometimes and I will never be able to mother my SS the way my husband wants me to...that’s a guilt I’ve let go. But there’s a duality here.. because I deeply want to be involved. I love my SS. I love my family. And I can’t sit back and have decisions being made around me that will directly impact my life. So I’ve made up my own expectations. I’ve established what my “role” means to ME, and have communicated accordingly.⁣
⁣
Here’s my tidbit of wisdom:⁣
What’s your role?⁣
𝐀𝐧𝐲𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐘𝐎𝐔 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐢𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞. ⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

We can’t wait for all the stars to align… our lives are happening now. ✨⁣
⁣
I talk to so many stepmoms who feel they’re waiting to…⁣
Buy a home…⁣
Move to where they want…⁣
Get the job they want…⁣
Have a baby…⁣
Love freely with their partner …⁣
Feel like they can breathe…⁣
⁣
The stress of blended life can feel and BE all consuming. Maybe you can’t go on the vacations you want or plan the wedding you’ve been dreaming of because .. child support, court fees .. kids are expensive. Maybe you’re scared of bringing a baby into the mix because the stress of the ex; you don’t want any negativity to impact your experience. I see you, mama. I see your frustration, desperation and resentment. ⁣
⁣
Know you deserve the life you dream of. ⁣
Know many of these things are temporary.⁣
Know there’s a lot out of your control - but so much still is. ⁣
Know there may never be a “right time” and you don’t have to put your life and happiness on hold. ⁣
⁣
Time will pass regardless and we can’t wait for things to fall into place - or someone to get their shit together for us to live the lives we want. ⁣
⁣
If you’ve needed a reminder, this is it: ⁣
You, your dreams, your happiness all matter and it’s up to you to make them priority. ⁣
⁣

Yea…. I am not okay… 😂😩⁣
⁣
There is no doubt in my mind my husband is the person I’m meant to be with. He grounds me, he inspires me, he’s loyal, makes me laugh and holds me when I cry. Under his rough Leo exterior, he’s compassionate and tender. He makes a damn good breakfast, has an ass that won’t quit (sorry, love🤪) and is truly my partner in life….⁣
⁣
So when we argue it’s only when we’re mad at the ex. Exhausted from the drama. Resentful of the life that revolves around a legal document and a woman who doesn’t have our son’s best interest at heart… we argue and it’s heartbreaking. I feel alone and  I spiral into questioning everything… I hate it. If only we didn’t have this dynamic - we’d be perfect. Well, as perfect has normal can get. ⁣
⁣
If you feel this… remember how “blending” is innately hard. Remind yourself that you and your partner need that solid foundation to get through the hard shit. Trust the ebbs and flows of the seasons, continue to grow as a couple and improve your communication. And when it’s good… celebrate it and allow it to fuel you. Also lay those boundaries so this hard shit doesn’t corrode the beauty you have. ⁣
⁣
If they’re truly your partner - it’s always worth it. ⁣
⁣

invisible⁣
alone ⁣
disrespected ⁣
hopeless.⁣

Sometimes you’re reacting appropriately to an inappropriate amount of bullshit….⁣🤷🏻‍♀️
⁣
I’m always hearing stepmoms say, “I don’t know why this bugs me; it’s not that big of a deal.” I usually ask them to go deeper…what is this actually about? It’s then that they spill the patterns, the history, the compilation of instances where they’ve felt minimized, dismissed, overwhelmed and voiceless…⁣
⁣
If it’s a big deal to you then it deserves your attention. Ask yourself what core value or belief is being threatened. Ask yourself what needs to change or what you need to hear. ⁣
Advocate for yourselves, babes because you can’t rely on others to do it for you. ⁣
⁣
What was the last “small” thing that upset you? What was the bigger issue?⁣

Easier said than done, I know. But babes… this is the goal…⁣
⁣
Her comments aren’t barbs. Emails, texts and calls don’t make your stomach flip. You laugh at the absurdity. You feel in control. You know that regardless of what happens you’re safe. You and your partner are a team. ⁣
⁣
Protecting your peace looks like saying no when you need to. It’s standing up for yourself, your comfort level and your mental health. It’s not taking things personally. It’s knowing you can’t control everything and sometimes there’s comfort in acceptance. It’s taking time for you, investing in your joys and finding gratitude. ⁣
⁣
Sis, you deserve peace and this stepmom life you chose doesn’t have to be a barrier. Commit to silencing the chaos and make your joyous life loud. ⁣
⁣
Tell me… how do you protect your peace? ⁣
What’s something new you can try? ⁣

Those moments and seasons are there and we need them to recharge us….⁣
⁣
It’s in the hugs my SS gives me. The “thank yous” for making his favorite meal. It’s movie nights and watching him play with his sister. ⁣
⁣
Stepmotherhood can break your heart but we have to notice the moments that heal it. ⁣
⁣
We’re headed out for our annual family fishing trip. I look forward to it every year. The kids get fresh air. My SS is happy to be sitting by the water and not connected to a video game. We’re making memories and I soak it all in. ⁣
⁣
Wherever you’re at right now I encourage you to find something good. And next time you feel your heart warm, notice it and breathe it in.⁣
⁣
This is why we stay. ⁣

Overthinking and overreacting are my favorite hobbies! 😂 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
Am I furious? Do I really not care? Is this absolutely insane? Is this normal? Should I be upset about this, because I feel fine?⁣ Or do I?⁣⁣
🤷🏻‍♀️😣⁣⁣⁣
 ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
You know those moments... when you’re super pissed?  When you feel attacked or dismissed....angry or hurt. In these moments: breathe and assess what’s happening for you. Uncover the root, but gain perspective of the bigger picture. Assess what you need, and ask for it. What can you control? Nothing? Let it go. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣ ⁣⁣
Now, feeling like you’re under reacting could be two things: there’s either been growth or you’re burnt the fuck out and you’re numb. You care, but you don’t have the energy for it. If it’s growth, girl...celebrate it. 🥳Don’t trick yourself into thinking you need to react to something if there’s nothing there. If you’re numb, process what’s really going on…and maybe schedule with me ‘cause depletion is not sustainable. ⁣😘⁣⁣
⁣
How are you today? ⁣
What do you need to hear? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

You knew the children were a priority.You knew the mom would always be their mom…⁣
⁣
But did you anticipate feeling like you’re at the bottom of the list? ⁣
⁣
We have to manage sharing attention with our stepkids. They deserve that time with their parent - yet we battle the feelings of wanting to feel included and valued. We invest our energy and care into our stepkids - only to experience the jolt to the heart when they run back to their mom. No matter how much we give, sacrifice, and show up…she will always be their number one. It fucking stings sometimes, right? ⁣
⁣
These are the invisible emotions stepmoms carry. There’s an ache in our hearts to be at the top of the list. To be seen, and loved and valued. To be someone’s world, number one and safe space. We deserve that. ⁣
⁣
This dynamic may be inherent - but your feelings matter. You deserve to feel important. You’re not a placeholder; you’re the missing piece.⁣
⁣
I see your heartache. ⁣
I feel your heartache. ⁣
You’re not alone. ⁣

Why is this even an argument? 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
I get it. Biology. Mama Bear. The “real mom”⁣yada-yada… ⁣

You don’t have to expel a child from your body to have observations, opinions, expectations or struggles. You shouldn’t have to say, “oh, but I love my stepkid” right after you say they’re annoying. You may not have labored your stepkids into this world, but you’re putting in the hard work, love and commitment as they’re growing up in it. ⁣

Spare us the golden uterus mentality - it won’t work here. ✨⁣

Choosing to step back might be necessary…but what if it leaves you feeling lonely? ⁣
⁣
If we’re not packing lunches, showing up to games, or helping make decisions … what are we doing? Are you just the babysitter? Does your partner feel less like a team? Do you feel less connected to your stepkids? ⁣
⁣
Do we really have to choose our peace over our purpose? ⁣
⁣
Sometimes - yes. ⁣
⁣
Sometimes making the choice to step back is exactly what you and your family needs to grow and evolve. Sometimes the kids need more of your connection and less of your correction. Sometimes your partner needs to step up and facilitate your role and how you’re included and welcomed in. ⁣
⁣
For those of you who’ve taken steps to disengage… did you feel less valuable? Did you feel more peace? Does it feel like you’re sacrificing one of the other? How do you step back but still feel like you’re contributing and part of the family? ⁣

There’s a whole bag of emotions ….⁣
⁣
I hear from so many frustrated stepmoms who watch their partners deal with harassment and chaos, all because they don’t want to upset the ex or go back to court. It’s infuriating to watch our partners live in fear of losing their kids because they set a boundary with the ex or simply stand up for their rights as a parent. ⁣
⁣
It’s also extremely frustrating to watch our partners not parent the way they want to because they don’t want to upset their kids. The partners who won’t enforce chores, structure or consequences because they fear they’ll choose their mom and won’t come home anymore. As a stepmom who’s not the “preferred house” I know my husband picks and chooses what he enforces, hoping we’ll gain a few “cool points”. ⁣
⁣
This dynamic is hard for our partners. I have so much compassion for the position they’re in. I imagine it feels there’s no “right” choice. However, what I’ve seen in the years of coaching stepmoms is this: the health of the relationship is being threatened when our partners continue to accommodate the exes emotions and parenting through fear of upsetting the kids isn’t always sustainable or actually in the true best interest of the kids. ⁣
⁣
Sending love to all of you who have this dynamic. This shit isn’t easy, your feelings are valid, there are ways to navigate it and you aren’t alone. ⁣
⁣

Question: “Why do I care more than the other parents?!”⁣
⁣
Answer: Either by our own doing, or by societal standards, stepparents carry a different load of expectations compared to the “real” parents.⁣
⁣
I feel I have to work harder, while the “real parents” can sit back and relax. A Biomom could forget to pack a lunch or warm coat and it’s no big deal. But what happens when a stepmom does it? There are things my husband or the ex could care less about, yet my worries keep me up at night. WTF.⁣
⁣
There’s a special rage I feel because of this dynamic - when I feel I’m the only one taking this parenting thing seriously...and it’s a major contributor to any resentment I hold. ⁣
⁣
Here’s what we have to remember: 𝐒𝐭𝐞𝐩𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐡𝐮𝐦𝐚𝐧. If we’re going to be given grace and the space to BE HUMAN it starts by holding ourselves to more realistic standards. Perhaps even the same standards as the actual parents - what a thought. ⁣
⁣
When I have minimal control (especially of the other house) I get to choose where my energy goes. And what I’ve learned is sometimes it’s best to parent a bit less and be a partner a bit more. ⁣
⁣
If you’re feeling the rage, you’re not alone. ⁣
But there’s something you can do about it. ⁣
I can help. 😘⁣
⁣✨Swipe for BONUS!

I’m just along for the ride on the ex’s emotional rollercoaster...⁣⁣
⁣⁣
She fights it when I show up to MD appts or school meetings, “you need to back off.” But then she sends over a gift on Mother’s Day. She asks my opinion on the therapist we’re  pursuing, but won’t acknowledge I’m the one who’s providing the insurance. She doesn’t want my SS to call me “mom”, but wants me to help with homework, get his haircut and rub essential oils on his feet. Oh, okay...⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So she wants me to show up in ways like paying for things and doing the things she doesn’t want to do, but she doesn’t want me to be seen as a parent or eclipse her as a mother - I get it now. ⁣Her emotions and ego are fragile. If it’s not her idea, it’s squashed. She sees I’m not going anywhere, but she wants to be in control over where I fit. ⁣
⁣⁣
As stepmoms, we’re expected to just “know our place” while that boundary line continues to be moved around to cater to ex’s emotional maturity at the time.⁣
⁣⁣
If you feel like you’re being pushed around, like you’re constantly waiting for the ex’s next emotional drop - then it’s up to you to get off the ride. 🎢 Create your own boundaries... pave your own lane and start saying “no”. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Ya feel me? ⁣⁣

Who can relate…?⁣
⁣
Being celebrated might feel weird. Like you don’t deserve it or it’s not yours to own. You’re not their “real” mom. It might feel too soon…do the kids even see you that way? Maybe you want to only celebrate if you’ve had your “own” baby. ⁣
⁣
But not being acknowledged doesn’t feel quite right either. You do a lot for your family. You ARE doing the mom things. You are a stepMOM after all. Aunts and even dog moms get celebrated…surly you could at least get a card? ⁣
⁣
These feelings are confusing but know they’re valid. If you’re feeling conflicted… communicate it to your partner. It might sound like this:⁣
⁣
“Hey babe, with Mother’s Day coming up I have some feelings about it. While I want to be acknowledged for what I do for you and the kids, I feel like it would be weird for me to be celebrated.” ⁣
⁣
Or ⁣
⁣
“It would mean a lot if I felt seen on Mother’s Day. Can we celebrate in some way?”⁣
⁣
Or⁣
⁣
“I don’t need the kids to celebrate me on Mother’s Day, but I would love to feel appreciated by you.” ⁣
⁣
What matters here is you’re communicating what you feel and need to your partner. You’re opening up a conversation so you can express any conflicting feelings. Give them the opportunity to love and support you, however that looks. ⁣
⁣
Does this resonate for you? ⁣
How you feelin’?⁣
⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

We didn’t get nine months to transition into parenthood and it shows...😑⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We didn’t get to have just “us” time with our partners. We didn’t have the moments of just fantasizing about what parenting together would be like. NOPE. We “signed up for” the expedited version of parenthood. Not only were we getting to know and falling in love with our partners, but we were taking on littles, a custody schedule and an ex. ⁣⁣⁣
If it feels hard, that’s because it is. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Feeling a little overwhelmed? Anxious? A bit of grief? Confused? In love but also sad?⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
You’re not doing anything wrong; your feelings are pretty normal considering the circumstances. Which is why it’s so important we stay grounded, slow things down and focus on the relationship we’re here for. Just because we’re stepmoms, doesn’t mean we have to miss out on the dating, being the girlfriend, fiancé or wife. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
This is innately hard shit.⁣⁣⁣
Your feelings are valid.⁣⁣⁣
You’re not alone. ⁣⁣⁣
Be gentle with yourself. ⁣⁣⁣

Answering “how are you?” to my non-stepmom friends, makes me feel insane.⁣
⁣
 “Normal” stepmom issues seem foreign and crazy to others. Describing my daily life, worries and stressors sounds straight out of a movie or really bad talk show...𝘐 𝘤𝘢𝘯’𝘵 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘴𝘩𝘪𝘵 𝘶𝘱. ⁣
⁣

To be honest I envy their lives sometimes. “You mean you never have to hear from their ex?” ... “You mean your life doesn’t revolve around a custody schedule?” … “You mean Mother’s a day doesn’t cause anxiety and heartache?” Oh the freedom, the security... the possibilities! ⁣
⁣

Tag a friend who gets it, give them some love. We need them. ⁣

Repeat after me…⁣
⁣
“I am not her and she is not me.” ⁣
⁣
I can be pissed my SS’s mom continues to put crap food in his lunchbox. Why wouldn’t she want him to eat healthier? I could get frustrated she doesn’t celebrate him on his birthday. How can she let him down like that? How can she be so disrespectful, needy, unorganized…I’ll never understand… because I’m not her. ⁣
⁣
I have to release her from my expectations because they’re only harming me. She doesn’t care if she disappoints me. So while I would love for her to be better, different, more or less something…I have no control over how she chooses to be a mom. I can have all the opinions but mine certainly aren’t going to change her. ⁣
⁣
When I notice my frustration towards her is rooted in what I would expect for myself…I have to shift my thinking. It’s easier said than done, it’s a practice… but it’s way better than holding onto shit that only burns me. ⁣
⁣
Who else needed this reminder?⁣
⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

There are amazing stepmoms EVERYWHERE…⁣
⁣
If a stepmom posts about how she shows up for their stepkid there are two types of commenters. The ones who say “that’s nice but you’re not the mom” and those who say “you’re amazing! I wish all stepmoms were like you!” Both comments are wildly confused. But let’s focus on the second one…⁣
⁣
MOST stepmoms are amazing, thoughtful, loving, warm and kind. They don’t carry around poison apples, they aren’t trying to send the kids off to boarding school, they aren’t hateful and evil. They show up, give a shit and are trying to carve out space in their family. ⁣
⁣
But people see what they want to see and attach their own shit to our story. For whatever reason, people will assume the worst in us until proven otherwise. They think amazing stepmoms are an exception, not the rule. ⁣
⁣
So here are some comments I would drop on your stepmom post…⁣
“You’re an amazing stepmom”⁣
“I love how you show up for your family.”⁣
“I can see how much you care.” ⁣
“You are so valued and important.” ⁣
“Stepmoms are f*cking amazing and though I know it’s hard you’re killing it.” 😉⁣
⁣
What comments would you like to see? ⁣
How can we start responding to the wildly dumb ones? 😂⁣
⁣

Where’s the lie? 🤔⁣
⁣
You don’t HAVE TO do more. But it’s not always that easy to just NOT do it. Stepmotherhood is complicated and while disengaging can be a tool, it doesn’t always feel productive or true to who you are. ⁣
⁣
When the ex doesn’t celebrate my SS’s birthday. When she doesn’t buy him appropriate fitting clothes. When she makes him more anxious and scared so I’m there to support and encourage him. What am I supposed to do? If my SS’s best interests are at heart - how do I step away from him? I certainly could … but that’s not who I am. ⁣
⁣
The full-time stepmoms know what I’m talking about. Any stepmom who feels they are doing so much more than their “real mom” and getting minimal recognition or appreciation. When the ex can do the bare minimum and still get praise and parades. It’s infuriating and these feelings could eat us alive. But they don’t have to…⁣
⁣
I have come to accept this dynamic in step motherhood. I may have to step up because of her lack of parenting - but I find peace and pride in myself knowing that I can’t stepmom any other way. This journey isn’t about her (though it feels like it, doesn’t it?) so I focus on my partner, my kids and my family. I disengage as needed for my own mental health but I continue to love and parent the only way I know how. While resentment lingers like a weed, I pull it so it can’t grow. She isn’t me and I am not her. She sucks and I’m awesome 🤪⁣
⁣
Can you relate? How do you manage these feelings? What keeps you strong?⁣

It can be a hard feeling to identify loneliness. As a stepmom....⁣
⁣
You could be surrounded by others throughout the day and still experience a deep and pervasive loneliness. Maybe you feel a lack of connection with your partner. ⁣
Maybe you feel left out within your blended family. Maybe you’re not feeling connected to your stepkid(s). ⁣
⁣
Or maybe it’s none of that...and the deepest loneliness is felt because you feel you can’t talk about the things weighing heavy on you...⁣
⁣
Your partner may not understand your feelings, so you’ve stopped sharing. ⁣
Your parents don’t understand why you “put up with it”.⁣
And your friends...aren’t stepmoms and just think your life is chaos and are tired of the “gossip.” ⁣
⁣
If any of this resonates with you...if you’re feeling isolated in your own heart and mind...⁣
know you’re among a community of others like you. ⁣
⁣

⁣
You may 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭 lonely, but you are not alone. ⁣

What do you do when you’re questioning it all??⁣
⁣
⁣
I shared my answer in stories last week (second slide) and I received so many DMs stating they often question if they’re cut out for this role. I get it. ⁣
⁣
Stepmotherhood has its joys. Sometimes I feel privileged to be a part of if SS’s life. Other times it feels like a burden. I grieve the life I’ll never know, while also feeling so damn grateful for the life I’ve built with my husband. ⁣
⁣
This shit is complicated and when our feelings get the better of us, daydreaming of walking away can feel relieving. ⁣
⁣
As I share in the second slide I start with assessing my own needs and what I have control over. I recognize that I go through seasons and I have to focus on growth and grace. I know that my life is full of joy and my feelings are temporary…⁣
⁣
So stepmom, what makes you stay? ⁣
What helps you when you find yourself questioning it all? ⁣

Ah yes… the classic inflexibility accusation. 🙃⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Raise your hand if you’ve ever heard “well you never said no before you got your little girlfriend.” 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
What she meant to say was, “I once was able to control you and now I can’t.”⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Especially during summer schedules and vacations when “favors” are being asked. While we want to be accommodating and there should be a level of flexibility, saying “yes” should not be said at the sacrifice of boundaries or a form of control.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Sending love to all of you who navigate this. Those who are trying to be reasonably flexible but are forced into manipulative conversations. Those who are trying to hold their boundaries but are being made to be the bad guys. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Do what’s best for your home. Stay strong as a couple and see through the words she’s saying.⁣⁣⁣
You aren’t alone. ⁣⁣⁣

I get it… we don’t always know where we stand. We’re not always welcome… ⁣
⁣
⁣
But sometimes that’s a them issue and not a you issue. If you’ve helped with the homework and the science projects, you deserve to show up to the graduation or the end of year events. If you want a picture with them at the dance recital or you want to cheer them on in the stands… do it. ⁣
⁣
Often times we’re waiting for an invitation. Sometimes we’re nervous about how others will perceive us. Many of us are worried about the ex and what she’ll say, the chaos that would ensue if she knew, or saw or had to be confronted with the reality that you exist. ⁣
⁣
You’re here and she’s got her own journey of acceptance. ⁣
⁣
Now, I’m not saying be high conflict. I’m not saying be disrespectful. What I am saying is don’t  dim your light or make yourself smaller. ⁣
I am saying you have a right to love, enjoy and be welcomed into your family. TAKE UP SPACE.⁣
⁣
So whether it’s teachers, coaches, in-laws, the ex… only you and your partner can model how you show up and where you stand. ⁣
⁣
Quiet that doubt. ⁣
You are worthy. ⁣
⁣

There’s freedom in adjusting expectations…⁣
⁣
As stepmoms we are in the middle of two other parents with their own styles of parenting. Things can get complicated when you don’t agree with your partner’s parenting style. And it can get really frustrating when you’re up against the differences from the other home. ⁣
⁣
“I wouldn’t handle it that way.” ⁣
⁣
“I would never do that to my own kid.” ⁣
⁣
Ever take your stepkids somewhere and feel embarrassed by their behavior? “That’s not on me…their mom let’s them get away with everything.” ⁣
⁣
We are actively participating in the parenting but feel we have to tiptoe around sharing our thoughts, opinions or ideas. We don’t want to criticize or throw gas on the high conflict fire. We want to parent our stepkids like they’re “our own” but how much control or influence do we really have? ⁣
⁣
There is freedom in letting go of the comparison. I have been more successful in having conversations with my partner about our differences and coming to a compromise than getting frustrated that he’s doing things differently than I would. I have been happier accepting I have no control over how my SS’s mom parents and content knowing I have some (albeit minor) influence when he’s in our home.⁣
⁣
But honestly….Sometimes your biggest effort of self care may be saying, “You two can figure this one out.” 🍿⁣
⁣

There are the dads who truly walk away and avoid supporting their kids…then there are the dads….⁣
⁣
Who are fighting to be part of their kids lives.⁣
There are the dads who are spending thousands and thousands for family court only to be told they’re not as important as the mom, they should get less time and the only way they can contribute is by paying child support. There are the dads that have to watch their every move because there’s a mother whose one wish is to push them away and then play victim. ⁣
⁣
My partner is one of those dads. ⁣
⁣
He loves his son and from the moment he was born he had to fight to be part of his life. Years of court dates and thousands of dollars later he was able to gain 50/50 custody - when only every other weekend was offered. To this day, BM will dismiss my husband’s contributions and importance in my SS’s life. WHY? ⁣
⁣
Why are dads minimized and seen as less than? Why do we live in a society that makes it a challenge to be a father, shames a man for not being present and then celebrates the stepdad who decided to “step up”? ⁣
⁣
It’s maddening when we see the love our partners have for their children and it’s not celebrated. It’s heart breaking to watch our partners mourn their children because of alienation. ⁣
⁣
To all the stepmoms who feel this and have partners who are still fighting to be present in their kids’ lives … I see you. ⁣
 ⁣

When I feel disconnected from my partner...my role as a stepmom is harder to navigate. ⁣
⁣
What is my role? ⁣
Am I doing it wrong? ⁣
Am I not doing enough?⁣
Am I doing too much? ⁣
I should back off. ⁣
I should stand up for myself. ⁣
Is it okay I do this? ⁣
Do I need too much? ⁣
What do I need?⁣ ⁣
Our partners are often our guides and without their support and encouragement we can feel lost and question everything. We’re in this for them, after all. ⁣
⁣
This is why I will always say:⁣
Your relationship and partnership comes first. Above the kids, about the family unit. Communicate. Overly communicate. Lean into one another and talk about the hard stuff. Disagree. Compromise. Validate. Share. Listen. ⁣
⁣
Sometimes when you want to run away, you just need your partner to pull you closer. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

It’s certainly what it feels like….⁣⁣🫠
⁣⁣
Whether it’s someone telling me directly or to a stranger in a comment thread, hearing “you chose this” or “you shouldn’t be a stepmom if….” is frustrating and deflating. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Yes, it takes a strong ass woman to take on this role and yea, it’s not for everyone. But most often these comments are directed at stepmoms who are trying to find their place, their comfort level, their boundaries and their happiness. All while trying to tiptoe around the life and expectations created before them. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
If a stepmom doesn’t love the kids like her own… “you shouldn’t be a stepmom.”⁣⁣
If she shares her struggles or frustration…⁣⁣
“You knew what you were getting into.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s all crap. Stepmoms can’t be expected to just accept everything as is and if she doesn’t she must not be cut out for it. If you don’t want the ex in your home - that should be okay. If you don’t always like your stepkids - that’s okay, kids are weird and love isn’t guaranteed. If you just want a vacation with your partner because dammit you need connection and intimacy and you just want to be a partner not a parent for once - do it! ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
None of what you’re feeling makes you a bad stepmom. And none of what you’re navigating is yours to do alone. It’s not your sole purpose to accommodate the nuclear family that no longer exists. Most importantly your partner has to make room for you to exist, with all your hopes, needs and desires. ⁣If they didn’t want things to shift and change, maybe THEY shouldn’t have started dating. Maybe they aren’t cut out for blended life. 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣⁣
You may have chosen to be a stepmom, but never think that means abandoning who you are to fit into a mold that’s unrealistic and wildly outdated. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Yup…I chose to be a stepmom AND I deserve to be happy. ⁣
⁣🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Exhibit A: Father’s Day….🥴⁣
⁣⁣
We’ll see TikTok’s and posts applauding all the men who “stepped up” and took on fatherhood with pride! There won’t be comments saying “what about the dad?” Or “stay in your lane”. Nope.  I predict there will be even be more card options and mugs declaring “Bonus Dads” are appreciated and loved and admired. They are all deserving of this, of course - seriously ♥️ But as we witnessed last month, stepmoms are not celebrated with the same bold affection. ⁣
⁣
There has been some progress in mainstream media.  But Stepdads are still seen as the hero (albeit sometimes they’re portrayed as creepy), while stepmoms are (almost always) the villain. It’s acceptable and applauded for men to swoop in and step up to fatherhood. Meanwhile women need to stay in their lane and not disrespect the mother’s role. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I think there are so many constructs at play… whether it’s gender roles, the way we’re taught at an early age to compete with other women, the identity of motherhood and the evolution of fatherhood. I won’t stand on my soapbox too long…😂⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Let’s chat about it. ⁣⁣
What are the differences and why? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

Sometimes it’s all I think about…😵‍💫⁣
⁣
How am I showing up? Is it too much? Am I overreacting or under-reacting? Do I need a boundary? Sure… In a really great way, being a stepmom has change me. It’s opened my heart up to a love I wasn’t expecting. It’s challenged me and strengthened me and I’m proud of who I am, but damn am I tired. And damn do I miss the parts of me that didn’t need to be so strong and resilient. ⁣
⁣
Here’s your reminder, stepmom. ⁣
You are so much more than who you are to your stepkids. You are so much more than the parental teammate you are to your partner. You are so much more than the buffer, the organizer, and the manager. You are MORE. ⁣
⁣
If you’re feeling a little lost and not knowing who you really are anymore, I encourage you to go back to the basics. What makes your soul feel good. Where do you feel most yourself? Who in your life celebrates you and truly makes you feel seen? ⁣
⁣
Don’t allow the stepmom life to consume you. Don’t let it be all you read about and all that you're working on. Invest in the other parts of yourself. ⁣
⁣
She deserves it. 🫶🏻⁣
Who needed this reminder?⁣

I don’t want to compete.😑⁣
⁣
We’re the stepmom…so we are by default forced into being compared to the ex, the other mom, the “real mom”. People do it intentionally and unintentionally and it’s fucking infuriating and heartbreaking. ⁣
⁣
Society and strangers do it when they see me and my SS together. “How does his mom feel about you doing that?” My answer: “I don’t know but I don’t do it for her, I do it for him.” ⁣
⁣
My in-laws did it when we we got married, when I was pregnant and in small comments like “Oh she would never do that.” Sometimes it feels like a compliment… sometimes I feel can’t just mother and love the way I want to - it’s always held up to the way she does it. ⁣
⁣
My stepson does it the most. In many ways I know it’s normal, but for so many reasons it cuts me deep. ⁣
⁣
“My mom doesn’t do it like that.” ⁣
“But my mom does this for me.”⁣
“That’s different than my mom’s.” ⁣
⁣
I don’t want to participate in a competition but sometimes I feel I am forced to. Sometimes I feel I have to dismiss my own levels of comfort, do things differently or show up in a way that’s not authentic to who I really am. And then the moment I do…I’m told I shouldn’t compete, I’m being petty, I should step back…she’s the mom. ⁣
⁣
She IS mom and I am ME and that’s all I truly want. We did not ask for this competition, and our participation is irrelevant as we’ll never win. ⁣
⁣
So my radical sisters… ⁣
I encourage you to stay true to who you really are. Do things for your family based on your own love, not the pressure of who she is or what she does. Easier said than done, I know. ⁣
⁣
How do you handle the comparisons? ⁣
How do you manage your urge to compete?⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Blended life impacts my marriage and I hate it…😒⁣
⁣
Whether it’s feeling misunderstood or unsupported in my role….the stress of a custody schedule, navigating the relationship with my stepson, parenting style differences, or the inevitable and unavoidable chaos from the ex… my husband and I have argued about it all. ⁣
⁣
Nothing makes me feel more disconnected from my partner than arguing about this stuff. Nothing makes me feel more resentful than thinking our marriage would be different if this blended dynamic didn't exist. What would it be like? I get sad thinking about how much happier we would be…⁣
⁣
Anyone else? ⁣
⁣
This is the grief I carry and I have to acknowledge it to move through it. This is my source of resentment, but I have to find acceptance that this is my reality. Because at the end of the day, I will choose my husband over and over again. My husband and I may have disagreements about blended family shit, but it’s on us to protect our marriage and home from the chaos. Daydreaming about a life I’ll never have prevents me from celebrating what we’ve created together. I HAVE to remember this…⁣
⁣
Who needs this reminder too? ⁣
How has your relationship been impacted by blended life? How has it made you stronger? ⁣
⁣

It may be hurtful to acknowledge, but their grief matters too…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
I remember the day my mom explained my parents were getting divorced. I remember being introduced to my stepdad and my dad’s girlfriends and later stepmoms. I felt a loyalty to my mother, though my heart ached to feel closer to my dad. Birthdays and graduations were accompanied by discomfort among the adults, despite their best efforts to hide it and get along. And if I’m being honest…Even as an adult, I still have this fantasy of parent-trapping my parents and making them fall in love again... over 25 years later. Which is wild because I truly do love my dad’s wife - hi, Lisa 😘 I didn’t know it then, but I was grieving the life I would never have. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
My stepson has never known his parents together. But he still asks why we can’t all live together. He doesn’t even know what he’s missing...but he senses a void. I feel for him. I hold compassion for him, even if what he’s says is hurtful to the family me and his dad have created. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Our stepkids will say or do things that cut us to the core. While we’re tending to our own grief, they’ll remind us of the memories we aren’t a part of and make us question our strength. Know their feelings have nothing to do with you. This is part of their process and what they may need most is compassion. Stepmama, I see you. I know it’s hard. ⁣
⁣⁣
How do you support your stepkids through grief? How do you support yourself? ⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Stepmoms are everywhere… so why do we feel so alone? ⁣
⁣
Maybe it’s the stigma the media portrays? Stepmoms are questioned for everything. Our existence always needs to be justified…⁣
⁣
Maybe it’s the way we feel with our friends and family? They don’t get it. They’re not stepmoms. They think we’re just aunts or babysitters, questioning why we care so much or why we’re involved.⁣
⁣
Maybe it’s within our own home? Our partners don’t know how to let us in or hold us to unsaid expectations. Our stepkids literally see right through us and we’re just supposed to not take it personally? ⁣
⁣
We’re not supposed to make it about us… but damn could it be about us for once? ⁣
⁣
If you feel invisible today or any day… know that I see you. You’re not alone. ⁣

Drop some love for yourself and others who need it. 🫶🏻⁣

You will never see a family photo of me with the ex in a matching jersey...🙅🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
I see the posts on the gram....A mom and a stepmom...hugging, laughing... #blendedgoals #coparentingwin ... They did it. They conquered the drama and they’re friends ... “all for the kids”. ⁣
⁣
That’s super fucking fantastic for them. Seriously... bravo. 👏🏼 But there’s not one single part of me that wants that relationship. Even if the ex had it in her to lay the weapons down and be a decent person, I would never willingly put effort into a close friendship. Just because she had a child with my partner doesn’t mean I need to be friends with her.⁣
⁣
If the joint parties and family photos aren’t an option or aren’t even welcomed in your dynamic...That’s okay. Our kids will turn out just fine. My SS doesn’t need to see us all love each other. What’s most important is him seeing us love him. ⁣
⁣
Don’t let social media make you question your boundaries, your success as a stepmom or the goals of your family. Especially when it’s for the sake of your mental health. ⁣
⁣
Let’s normalize #parallelparentinggoals ⁣
⁣

My partner as the EX and my partner as a PARENT are two different things…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
First I’ll say: Our partners were not perfect in their previous relationships - no matter what they say. 😂 Even if the ex was awful, I’m sure our partners all played a part and were jerks at time. But so often I see exes lashing out because of the history and hurt from the broken relationship, and dismissing who they are as parents. BM once said to me, “I hope he treats you better than he treated me.” and it was a peek into how her brain works.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You can be a crappy partner but still be a great parent. You can despise them, but still respect them for who they are in your kid’s life. “Healthy co-parenting” can happen when the history and hurt of the relationship doesn’t impact the role of parenting. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Now if the exes/BMs could understand this, that would be great. ⁣⁣
⁣Thoughts? 🤔⁣
⁣

Are there free returns on this package? 😜⁣
⁣
I fell in love and he had a kid. I figured there would be sticky fingers, tantrums, tough parenting decisions. I knew it wouldn’t be easy… but I didn’t know I would be hated for breathing, be tossed into court battles, argue with my partner about his ex, and slowly lose my mind and sometimes my will to keep going….⁣
⁣
Ya feel me? ⁣
⁣⁣
Ugh. Nothing prepares you for motherhood, and stepmotherhood is no different.⁣

People can just shut their ignorant mouths with the “you knew what you signed up for” because all I wanted was peanuts and I got a whole ass circus. 🥜🎪🤡⁣

Even if it’s nothing like what we had planned or envisioned, we belong here. 💓⁣
⁣
A stepmom recently reached out and shared an “ah-ha” moment. She explained she’s spent the last several years wondering “WHY ME?” Why does she have to learn to navigate HC? Why does her partner have to deal with this? She’s a good person, kind and caring…doesn’t she deserve the same in return? ⁣
⁣
How many have thought the same? ⁣
⁣
She continued to share her realization: she was meant for this. Whether it be God or the universe…. This was the plan all along. Sometimes other people need our goodness, our kindness and our influence and that’s our purpose. Though it’s wildly different than what we had planned for ourselves…. Sometimes the plan is bigger than us. ⁣
⁣
I too had this revelation years into my journey. I fully believe that everything in my life was preparing me to be my husband’s wife and my son’s stepmom. Though it’s challenging and I sometimes feel I’m not cut out for it, I know I was built for this. I know I was meant for them.⁣
⁣
So stepmoms… I encourage you to reflect on your real WHY. Why did you find yourselves in this role? Know that you have a bigger purpose than what you’re seeing now. ⁣
⁣
Your partner and kids needed you.⁣
You’re right where you belong. ⁣
⁣
*Sending love and Birthday wishes to Abby🎉⁣

Stepparent alienation is common and it’s a heartbreaking dynamic to navigate ….⁣
⁣
First off, loyalty binds are real and strong. Our stepkids will often feel the tug to keep their biological parent happy or not hurt their feelings. Loyalty towards their parent is normal. ⁣
⁣
What I’m talking about here is the blatant attempts made by the biological parent to damage the relationship between stepmom and child. When our stepkids are made to feel like they can’t express they enjoy their stepmom because their mom would be upset. When the ex speaks poorly about the stepmom to the kid, and when our stepkids are seemingly forced to say negative things in order to receive love or just survive with their mom. ⁣
⁣
This is heartbreaking for the kids and for the stepmom. The ex is obviously motivated from a place of insecurity and control. And when we add in those loyalty binds our kids can get lost, causing long lasting issues. ⁣
⁣
If any of this sounds familiar - I’m pausing here to send you the biggest virtual hug. I know you’re wondering what I often wonder “who wouldn’t want someone else to love their kid?”.⁣
⁣
You’re not alone. And while I don’t have magic wand to make it all stop, please know this:⁣
The exes issues are hers alone. Continue to show up with love and kindness and prove her wrong; your stepkids will see it. Despite whatever she has to say about you, you know the truth and the kids do too - or at least have faith that they someday will. Know that your stepkids are trying to figure their own journey out and it’s confusing and sometimes scary.⁣
⁣
To all the stepmoms who have a great relationship with your stepkids (or are trying to) but are constantly up against the exes issues - you are seen. ⁣
⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

There’s no trust in high conflict…⁣
⁣
Therefore it’s easy to overthink it all. ⁣
⁣
I wish BM could just be transparent about things. Like who my SS is really hanging around… why she really didn’t make it to his graduation….why is she being so nice all of a sudden? While I don’t need nor want to know about her personal life, there are times that it most definitely impacts my SS and a little truth would be real refreshing. ⁣
⁣
Outsiders don’t get it. Outsiders don’t have the history of lies, manipulation and gaslighting. Outsiders hear us “overthinking” and assume we’re being harsh, crazy and not giving her the benefit of the doubt. As if I enjoy feeling hyper vigilant and protective of my home and family… ⁣
⁣
What would it be like to read an email and not think, “what isn’t she telling us?” ⁣
⁣
Drop a ♥️ if you can relate. ⁣

We may have “signed up for this” but we have expectations for our partners too…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Shoutout to all the partners who listen to us when we’re frustrated, overwhelmed, confused or battling a broken heart. Thank you to all the partners who acknowledge the difficulties of this stepmom role and are our landing place for comfort, belonging and the feeling of “home”. Thank you to all the partners who validate what we’re feeling without judgment. The partners who help facilitate the relationships with the stepkids and protect us from the barbs of the ex. They carry the load of their own baggage and celebrate the woman who came into their life; loving her however she wants to show up, because she didn’t know what the hell she was getting into. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Of course, this type of partnership doesn’t happen overnight. It does take trial and error, hard conversations and a commitment to growth to get to that space. But at the core of any healthy relationship is respect and the willingness to be both vulnerable and influenced.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We did not commit to our partners to be left feeling alone, misunderstood and made to question our own realities. We are not in these relationships to be silent about the things that matter to us or made to feel like the problem. We deserve better. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So sweet stepmoms. My hope for you is you have the supportive and loving partner you deserve. Give them some extra love today. And if you find yourself in the dark and have no partner to light your way, I hope you have the courage to light your own torch and walk away from what’s no longer good for you. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You’re a badass and you deserve to feel like it everyday. 🔥⁣⁣
⁣

How dare you…the audacity😂⁣
⁣
Okay, so I get asked a lot about how involved I am as a stepmom, and why/when I choose to disengage. Here’s my answer: ⁣
⁣
I want to be an active stepmom/parent. I want to be a supportive partner and parenting team with my husband. I want to be in my stepson’s life. I would not be able to be passive or hands-off; it’s just not me. BUT…I will never parent more than my partner or his two fully functioning parents. My mental, emotional and marital health, will always be a priority. When there’s an imbalance, that’s when I disengage, step back, tag my husband in while I sit on the bench and cheer him on. 📣 And I refuse to feel bad about it. ⁣
⁣
It seems ridiculous but we get caught up in all of the proving ourselves, our maternal instincts, our drive to find control in chaos and then we’re the ones fucking exhausted ⁣
and desperately asking our partners to step up. Naw girl. Assess and reassemble the parenting roles and expectations ‘cause there’s been a miscommunication. ⁣
⁣
What other ridiculous questions do you ask as a stepmom? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

It’s not my job to make her more comfortable...🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
I respect her as his mother. There are some instances where it is appropriate for me to pull back and let the light shine on her. I am not in competition, nor am I confused as to who his mother is. I want her to show up and be a mom; her absence is often the source of my frustration. ⁣
⁣
But will I show up to events and cheer my stepson on? Yes. Do I advocate for his physical and mental health in appointments? Absolutely. Do I express my opinions, observations and overall affection regarding him? Of course I do. ⁣
⁣
She would prefer I stay small. Invisible. She would prefer to not hear about my role in my family because it makes her uncomfortable and threatens her ego. While I can hold space and sympathy for her experience, I refuse to cut myself into pieces to be more easily digestible. ⁣
⁣
Choke on my awesomeness. ⁣

I have a confession...⁣
⁣
I look at non-blended families and I think about what that life would be like. I daydream of just being with my partner, JUST my partner - no ex tagging along. I think about raising kids together, without having the complexities of transition days, a custody order, hearing “my mom” and feeling like a visitor in my own home. What a life that must be... my heart aches. I get sad. It feels lonely. ⁣
⁣
That’s not the life I chose. My person came with two other people. I have to honor my sadness, but remind myself despite my longing to have met him first, I know I came into their lives at the right time. I know that while this role and this blended life is hard and relentless, I wouldn’t have chosen differently (tho I would have done it a different way, but that’s a different post 😂). I know with every ounce of my being I was meant to be his wife, his stepmom and her mama. ⁣
⁣
We may not be that nuclear family who has traditional worries (what are they btw? 😬) but we’re still a family who loves hard and can overcome whatever obstacles get thrown at us. ⁣
⁣
You may not have chosen the “easy” path, but do you feel this path was meant for you?⁣
⁣

Ever wonder why you’re SO tired after your SKs leave...? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Ever hesitate communicating to your partner how tiring it is to be around their kid(s)? ‘Cause they just won’t get it...?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You’re right, they won’t. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Being a stepmom takes an extreme amount of mental and emotional energy. We are constantly self-assessing, self-correcting and questioning what we can, can’t, should or should not do. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐𝘴 𝘪𝘵 𝘰𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝘐 𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘪𝘮 𝘵𝘰 𝘤𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘯 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘳𝘰𝘰𝘮?” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐 𝘣𝘦𝘵 𝘩𝘦 𝘭𝘪𝘬𝘦𝘴 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘮’𝘴 𝘴𝘱𝘢𝘨𝘩𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘪 𝘣𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘳.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘞𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘮 𝘐 𝘵𝘶𝘤𝘬 𝘩𝘪𝘮 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘦𝘥?” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“𝘐’𝘮 𝘨𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘴𝘩𝘪𝘵 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴, 𝘐’𝘮 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s constant, and we’re not even aware we’re doing it. We’re always gauging the appropriateness, the relationship, the impact... sometimes it’s not even until they leave that we notice we haven’t taken a breath in days. We feel drained, depleted and yes...relieved.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Biological parents don’t operate at the same level we do, it’s unique and hard to explain so if you’re feeling shame for it - I’m here to normalize it. ⁣
⁣⁣
Next time you need to justify your exhaustion to your partner, or better yet, your need for a break...let them know it’s not their kid(s) that are necessarily running you ragged....it’s your mind you can’t turn off. ⁣⁣
⁣

Nope, not real. Just pretending…🙄🤦🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s 2023 and somehow we’re still in a world that believes a child must exit your uterus for you to enter the community of motherhood. FFS.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I remember when I my stepson was 3yo…I took him to the park while my then boyfriend was working. I stood with other moms as we watched the kids climb and slide. I felt part of the club as we talked potty training, picky eaters and being a “threenager”. Their conversation shifted to postpartum, sleepless nights and breast or bottle. I got quiet. This experience was the first of many where I FELT like I was a mom but was quickly slapped with doubt…was I just pretending? Am I an imposter? If I didn’t “earn my stripes” can I still be recognized for how I show up now? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It took me a few years to really feel confident but the answer is YES. We may not have birthed them, but everything we do for them now fucking counts and it matters. I haven’t said it in awhile so here it is: Mom is a Verb. It’s in our actions, not our biology that makes us part of the club and I’m tired of society minimizing our role.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We’re in it. We’re doing it. Show up to those parks or sports events and stand with the other moms with your head held high. 👑If they question you, see it as an opportunity to educate them on what “real stepmoms” are. ‘Cause we’re badass and can’t be messed with. 😉⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When have you felt “less than” among other moms? How have your feelings evolved? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Hahaha well aren’t we silly. 😂⁣
⁣
Okay, so certainly things do get easier to a degree; can all you seasoned stepmoms attest to this? ⁣
⁣
But more realistically I’d say things don’t get easier so much as we get strong get and just learn to deal with them differently. OR once we figure out how to handle something it’s already changed and now we’re managing a brand new obstacle. 😩⁣
⁣
It took me several years to realize waiting for things to “calm down” was pointless. I had to get to a place of acceptance and put my gloves on and get dirty with the shit I needed to handle: ME. My need for control, my expectations, my grief, my resentment. Waiting for things to be easier was waiting for something to happen *to* me … and it wasn’t working. Our countdown to 18 could tick away but what life are we living in the meantime? Also - I hear there’s stepmom life beyond 18 so wtf then? 😂⁣
⁣
Remember: our seasons change and it won’t always be this version of hard. We just gotta keep getting wiser and stronger. 😘⁣
⁣
Tell me something that has gotten easier because *you’ve* made the change? ⁣

The transition was fast and furious 🥴😂⁣
⁣
I was living alone, and eating charcuterie in front of my favorite show every night. I was HAPPY. Then I met my person, his child and before I knew it I was cooking nuggets and trying to teach a 3yo table manners. I was very HAPPY but my cute little purse transitioned into a big bag of snacks and toys and all of a sudden there were crumbs everywhere… who had I become?! ⁣
⁣
For many of us this is just part of our journey. This is what happens when we are eager,⁣ committed and excited to be giving our hearts to our new relationship. I think what many of us want though is to be seen for this change and what feels like a major sacrifice. That just because we’re struggling, doesn’t mean we aren’t capable. We want our partners to acknowledge that maybe these changes aren’t coming easy and to hold some grace as we figure out this new identity. We need our partners to still support and nurture the woman they met, her dreams and her priorities  because they still matter. ⁣
⁣
The acts of being a stepparent can feel like it happens overnight, but our hearts need some time to catch up. 💓Even with great gain there can be grief. ⁣
⁣
Who can relate? What drastic shifts did you/are guy experiencing? What do you want your partner to acknowledge? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

Some people worry about their Alexa reporting their every move…Stepmoms worry about their stepkid. 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
I feel like I’m constantly being watched. It’s the obvious comments like, “My mom doesn’t do it that way.” ⁣But also my own internal insecurity...⁣“Will he tell his mom about this?” ⁣OR “We’ll get an email about this one.”🙄⁣
⁣⁣
My partner gets it…sort of, not really. He doesn’t carry the same emotional weight I do. He walks around with the privileged title of “Dad”, meanwhile I’m under a microscope with a target on my back. And the “just be yourself” advice does nothing for me. “Being my (awesome) self” is why she hates me. 😂 I’m sure you can relate…⁣
⁣
So how can we be comfortable in our homes? For me it’s remaining confident in who I am, and how my partner and I parent. Also, boundaries with the ex and honesty with my stepson. We say, “yup, your two homes are different” a lot.⁣
⁣
What helps you feel more at home and not in a fishbowl? ⁣

Don’t get it twisted…⁣
⁣
The days I don’t want to be a stepmom are the days that have me stressed and anxious because of the ex’s presence in my life. Stepmotherhood is harder when I argue with my partner about her behavior or how her behavior impacts my stepson. Not wanting to be a stepmom has very little to do with my stepson and a whole lot to do with circumstances. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
It’s okay if you don’t want to be a stepmom today…or tomorrow. It’s okay if it feels like too much, because it is. ⁣
⁣

✨New Episode! I chat with KC to discuss the often unspoken reality of men's mental health… ⁣
⁣
⁣
…through their divorce and into high conflict co-parenting. Women can be emotionally abusive too and many stepmoms are seeing the residual and continued trauma our partners experienced. How do we support them as they navigate their own healing? How do we advocate and protect our partners from more emotional abuse without being the scapegoat "villain"? Listen in! ⁣
⁣
About My Guest: ⁣
Hey! I'm KC a 25year old stepmom to two beautiful girls. I am a child of a high conflict divorce and now get to show up for my step kids the way my stepdad did for me. I'm from a small town in Alberta Canada and uprooted my entire life to move 7 hours away from my friends and family to be a stepmom. It's been quite the ride of healing and self discovery, but I'm still here for it all!!⁣

Family vacations are supposed to be fun, right?😫 Well....let’s normalize this for a moment. ⁣
⁣
Even “nuclear” or “traditional” families get a bit stressed with vacations. Taking the kids out of their element and into public is risky 🤣 There’s the packing and the traveling....the eeek! But stepparents tend to feel an added layer of stress and anxiety. ⁣
⁣
How will the kids behave around friends/family? ⁣
Will they be bored and complain? ⁣
Will the vacation be compared to the other house? ⁣
Will they just be counting down the minutes until they go back to their mom? ⁣
Will my partner be helpful? Will they see what I see and also be irritated? 😬⁣
Will you get one moment to just relax?⁣
⁣
Yikes. Deep breaths...⁣
⁣
For all the reasons listed above and a few more, we don’t take my stepson on every family vacation. If that’s something you want or something you already do...give yourself permission to not feel guilty about that. 😘⁣
⁣
Here are a few tips for when you are vacationing with the kid(s):⁣
☀️Lower your expectations...nope, lower. ⁣
☀️Have a plan (to assist in somewhat of a false sense of control🙃) but be flexible⁣
☀️Identify what you want out of your vacation and communicate it to your partner. Want a special date night? Establish a new tradition? Communicate and make it happen. ⁣
☀️Prepare for how you’ll manage your emotions when things get rough. Go for a walk. Call a friend. Send me a DM😘⁣
⁣
Family vacations can cause anxiety!⁣
But they don’t have to impact all the fun. ⁣
How do you handle family vacations? ⁣
What helps you lower the stress? ⁣
⁣

If “evil” is having boundaries and a voice then… 😈⁣
⁣
I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t like my SS in our bedroom. I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t always agree with my partner’s parenting decisions. I’m a good stepmom AND I don’t want to be friends with the ex. I’m a good stepmom AND transition days make me anxious, I love my “down time” and I don’t want every vacation to include my SS. ⁣
⁣
I’m not a good stepmom in spite of these things.⁣
I’m a good stepmom BECAUSE of them. I can be commited to my sweet little family and still have feelings, hopes and dreams, opinions,  goals, and amazing f*cking boundaries. ⁣
⁣
Stepmoms get ridiculed and judged if we don’t appease everyone, love our stepkid, want to be buddies with the ex, voice an opinion or just… exist. It can be tempting to just keep quiet, get smaller, abandon boundaries… but if we do then we risk losing ourselves in the process. Then what? Remember - you matter and you weren’t meant to be it all, solve it all or live up to everyone’s expectations. ⁣
⁣
We’re not evil; We’re radical. ✨⁣
⁣

To be fair… going above and beyond is kinda my nature. ⁣
⁣
So is being organized, on time, thoughtful and forgiving. Recovering people pleasers anywhere? 🙋🏻‍♀️Mix this with becoming a stepmom and I was destined to struggle with honoring my own damn boundaries and caring for my own mental health. ⁣
⁣
I often feel MORE pressure to show up and be awesome because I’m not his “real mom”. She can mess up or not show up and still get all the praise. I fumble because I’m human yet I don’t get the same grace. ⁣
⁣
I often feel I’m under a microscope and held to higher standards so I take the bait and show up, often more than the other two fully functioning parents. I have to check myself constantly…. ⁣
⁣
If my mental health and happiness is being threatened I pull back. I shouldn’t be working harder, worrying more or sacrificing it all. Even if it’s in my nature to step up…⁣
⁣
Does this resonate? ⁣

I’ll never scorn a woman for making the decision that’s best for her…⁣
⁣
I saw on a recent Instagram post a stepmom getting heat from walking away from a 3 year relationship because her partner gained full custody. She didn’t want to be a full-time stepmom. My thoughts: good for her. ⁣
⁣
Why is her character put into question because she decided to walk away? If she stayed and struggled would she not hear “you knew what you were getting into”? Damned if you do and damned if you don’t…⁣
⁣
If a woman does some soul searching and realizes she doesn’t wasn’t the responsibility, the custody schedule, the chaos, the drama then good for her for being true and honest to herself. Sometimes the relationship with our partners doesn’t actually make it “worth it”. Sometimes the relationship needs work too and that’s the real problem. ⁣
⁣
I talk to my non-stepmom friends and hear “I could never do what you do.” Just like I look at marathon runners, it takes a certain type of crazy to want to put yourself through that 😂 I’m no runner, but damn I’m a strong stepmom. ⁣
⁣
For me, it will always come down to the happiness of the woman and if this stepmom life isn’t for you - you will get no shame from me here. ⁣

Our partners may never understand our experiences, but they don’t have to…⁣
⁣
What they can do is sit with us in our feelings, listen without getting defensive and create a space for validation and support. ⁣
⁣
My husband will never know the discomfort I feel in my home sometimes. The pressure to mother in some ways and the guilt that I can’t mother in others. He may never understand my never ending quest for some sense of control. Or why I am may never again be that carefree woman be fell in love with. ⁣
⁣
Stepmotherhood changes you and our partners don’t need to fully understand that in order to validate our happiness and heartache. ⁣
⁣
Hearing, “I don’t understand, but I’m listening.” Or “thank you for sharing this with me, I’m sorry you’re feeling this way.” Or my favorite “do you need me to fix it or be here with you?” ⁣
⁣
This is the connection we often seek. ⁣
⁣
How does your partner support you? ⁣
Do you often fight for understanding or validation? ⁣
⁣⁣

And then everything in between…⁣
⁣
The good days remind you of your purpose, your strength and the happiness that exists all around you. Other days are for rest, a reset, an opportunity to look inward, your sign of an unmet need or just a reminder that you’re human. You need it all to survive because this shit is exhausting. ⁣
⁣
Be gentle with yourself. Whatever kind of day you’re having, let it be. If you’re having a great day, don’t start worrying about what’s coming next. If you’re having a crap day, don’t bully yourself into “staying positive”. Sit in it. You’re safe. You’re okay. ⁣
⁣
If you needed a reminder:⁣
You’re an amazing stepmom on good days and bad days. ⁣
⁣
And we’re all in it with you. ⁣
⁣

I shared my husband’s wise words with a stepmom recently…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
She was expressing a fear many of us have. The fear of what the ex will say or do if she learns of a choice you’ve made in your home. Will she be pissed if you asked them to clean their room? What will she do if she knows you took them to a birthday party? Are you allowed to do xy or z? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I get it. We fear the backlash. But how is this sustainable? When I come to my husband with these fears he reminds me that we can’t live our lives walking on eggshells or accommodating what she wants. We have to be confident in what we feel is right for our home, our family, our lives. We deserve to live authentically and not in fear. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Let her be mad. ⁣⁣
You are not responsible for her reaction. ⁣⁣
⁣
*shoutout to this stepmom: you got this 🫶🏻*⁣

We can’t do it all, babes. 😴⁣
⁣
Raise your hand if you’ve ever written court documents, felt like a trauma therapist or a mediator? 🙋🏻‍♀️It’s a lot to carry on top of our own stuff, but so many of us take it on hoping it will eventually get us to our goal: peace. ⁣
⁣
Valid. But it’s not sustainable. ⁣
⁣
There’s a different between support and fixing. As stepmoms this difference gets confusing and the boundaries pretty damn blurry - especially when we are wanting to find stability, control and healing in our blended family. Our intentions are good, we want to be helpful, but sometimes this leads to burnout, resentment and unhappiness.⁣
⁣
You may love them to pieces and be true teammates…but you can’t do it all for your partner. You can support them through the court process, but you aren’t their attorney. You can be their safe space, but you aren’t their therapist and can’t be their sole support in healing. We have to take off our many hats and be their partner. We have to invest in the relationship before we’re sucked dry.⁣
⁣
You are strong, stepmom. You are loving, smart and determined to thrive in your family, but you can’t do it alone and it’s not your responsibility fix it all and be everything to your partner. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣Who needed this reminder?

Sometimes I need to remember that it won’t always be this way…♥️⁣
⁣
We won’t always have the custody schedule guiding our lives. We won’t always have to communicate with the ex or feel her presence in our home. My stepson will grow up and our concerns will shift. I’m looking forward to the days when he’s coming to visit because he wants to. I want to hear about his mom’s choices and not feel the fear of how it will impact mine.⁣
⁣
I look to my husband’s stepmom for this reminder because seasoned stepmoms know…just because the kids are grown doesn’t mean stepmom life is over or “easy”. But damn I’ll be ready for the change in scenery because my current concerns are getting old and I’m tired. ⁣
⁣
I aim to validate my current feelings but remind myself that this is temporary. It’s soothing to focus on the future, but I don’t want to wish time away. It’s the conflict of staying present but hopeful for the day I’ll wake up with my husband and it will JUST be the stressors of OUR home.⁣
⁣
Be gentle with yourself now and know it won’t always be this way, mama. ⁣
⁣
Who needed this reminder? ⁣

I had so many hopes and dreams…😍⁣
⁣
I love kids. I always knew I wanted a family. When I met my guy and knew he was my forever guy… him having a kid WAS a bonus. We were going to be a family. I was confident in myself and knew my intentions were good. I’m smart, responsible and have lots of love to give. Be a stepmom? Awesome. The boys love me… I’m sure his mom will see me as a respectable person and we’ll get along just fine. ⁣
⁣
😂🤣🤦🏻‍♀️😂💀🫠⁣
⁣
What a naive little soul. ⁣
⁣
While many of my hopes and dreams have come true…it only happened because of a lot of blood, court, boundaries, sweat and countless tears. When I sort it all out, one of my bigger emotions I’ve navigated is GRIEF. ⁣
⁣
It’s grieving the loss of what I thought it would be. It’s grieving the firsts I’ll never have. It’s grieving my ideals of PEACE and what I want for just MY HOME and family. Grief is real and in stepmotherhood it can blindside you, and if you let it…it might swallow you whole.⁣
⁣
Name it. ⁣
Honor it. ⁣
Speak it out loud and give it room to breathe. ⁣
Know you didn’t know what you didn’t know and though shit didn’t go according to plan, the life your leading is deserving of celebration and joy. ⁣
⁣
Hold on to those hopes and good intentions - That’s what makes you radically wonderful. ⁣

What hopes did you have? How are they different?

Every time I do the “I’m an asshole” series I get these responses…⁣
⁣
I exist.⁣
I’m breathing.⁣
I show up.⁣
⁣
It can feel like high school, right? The pettiness. The snide behavior. The passive aggressive, or just outwardly aggressive comments....like, you’re straight up attempting to co-parent with a Mean Girl. Have we not evolved? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I feel in a huge way stepdads have it easier merely because women have this competition dynamic that’s been engrained in them since adolescence. Is she prettier than me? Funnier? More popular? Do the guys like her? And now in a step family situation - I have a mean girl who’s pissed because I have the guy and the kid. HER kid. She chooses to see it that way. She chooses to make it about herself. ⁣
⁣⁣
I dream of a world where women can encourage each other. Where there is no competition, and we celebrate one another for being awesome. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It starts with us, babes. Celebrate ourselves and one another, and let it spread like wildfire. 🔥⁣⁣
⁣

Love them like they’re your own, but don’t forget they’re not yours….⁣
⁣
Show up and be involved, but don’t make the ex look bad. Welcome them into your lives and heart, but keep a distance because they have a mom. Don’t treat them any different than you would your own child, but don’t forget they aren’t yours so your opinions, values and parenting styles don’t matter. ⁣
⁣
We can’t win, so I refuse to entertain this narrative. I refuse to live my life protecting the ego of the ex. You don’t like that I’m teaching him how to do his laundry, draw and garden? You don’t like that we have our own inside jokes and he loves our dance parties? You don’t like that he goes to my family functions and is treated like my son… how dare I. Sorry, not sorry. Those things all benefit him and that’s a YOU problem. ⁣
⁣
I won’t give him less so the ex feels better about herself; just BE better. ⁣
⁣
They can’t have it both ways. Only YOU decide how you want to show up and it’s not your responsibility to be smaller and more digestible. ⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣Who feels this?

And isn’t this sad? ⁣😔
⁣
Now - before I get all the comments about “well 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦 stepmoms do this” and “I am the 𝐌𝐎𝐌”. ⁣
I know. I am not supporting the idea that stepmoms should force kids to call them mom. And OMG we all know who the MOM is. 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
Here’s what I am saying…⁣
⁣
It’s often easier to think the stepmom must be forcing the kids to call her mom because how awful would it be to think the kids came up with it on their own. ⁣
⁣
If the kids feel comfortable calling the stepmom “mom” and the stepmom feels comfortable with it … what’s the problem? They feel safe. They feel loved. They feel close to another parent figure. A child should not feel confused or in the middle about what to call someone. They have enough to navigate in a blended family. Calling a stepmom “mom” is NOT an issue for the child. ⁣
⁣
A title doesn’t need to hold so much power. It doesn’t need to diminish someone’s value. There’s no confusion about who gave birth to the kids and when there’s a fight about it all that’s being revealed is a fragile ego. A child loving a stepmom does not take away from the mom, it gives to the child. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
It’s sad (infuriating) when these type of issues get brought up in court. This is not a court issue. This is an issue that should be brought up in therapy. ⁣@simondslawgroup 😉
⁣
Not all stepmoms want to be called mom. ⁣
Not all kids will call their stepmoms mom…⁣
But regardless of the title… “mom is a verb”⁣
And we’re doing it. ⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Seriously….you’re all amazing. 😍⁣
⁣
As we all know, there’s a stigma attached to our role. We’re home wreckers and kid haters. We’re full of jealousy and give poison apples. But in the years I’ve been getting to know hundreds of stepmoms… nothing could be further from the truth. ⁣
⁣
You are thoughtful and kind. You have hopes and dreams for your family and will make sacrifices (even when you shouldn’t) to fulfill them. I see you planning, caretaking, and running your home all while considering your stepkids’ and how they’ll feel. I see you striving to be the bigger person, even when it’s painful. I see you in love with your person and supporting them through all of the trials of co-parenting. ⁣
⁣
We may have hard feelings. We may struggle.⁣
We may develop feelings of resentment, sadness or grief. But that’s because we’re human… we’re not evil. ⁣
⁣
You’re the shit and don’t forget it. 😎⁣
⁣⁣
