Sometimes it feels no matter what we do, it’s never enough. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I’m well aware of this reality and it still cuts deep. Here’s the thing:⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I want my stepson’s mom to thrive. I want her to get her shit together, her priorities straight, put her big girl pants on and BE BETTER for him. But the truth is she continues to disappoint him, and still walks on water. ⁣Meanwhile, I know I can’t change her so I focus on what I can control: ME. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So I show up the way I want to show up and be the stepmom he deserves. I’m there to cheer him on, plan the summer fun, have the hard conversations, wipe the tears, buy the favorites, and show up at school events. I do the hard stuff, and she swoops in for the praise and admiration. ⁣⁣This is the reality for many of us…we do so much. I don’t always need a “thank you” but I’d certainly love to stop hearing shit like “you’re not mom”. His mom isn’t MOM, so just stop with your ignorance. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Now, sure I could stop doing all of it. We all could…Disengage. He’s not my kid. But I WANT to be there for him. He deserves this type of love and hype. It’s not his fault and pulling away from him and not showing up as me is doing us both a disservice. I may not get all the praise and appreciation, but that can’t be my biggest motivator: he is. She hates me for this, but the irony is…if she would step up maybe I wouldn’t feel compelled to be so involved. 🙄⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I’m not overwhelmed, I’m not even resentful. She’s mom and she can do no wrong; I get it. ⁣⁣⁣
Still doesn’t suck any less. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Who else feels this? ⁣⁣⁣
If you’re needing some extra support - comment “let’s chat” and I’ll send you a DM.🫶🏻
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

And…..who are you…..? 🤨⁣
⁣
“I’m the other mom. The one who got the school supplies, made sure he had a hair cut and felt emotionally prepared the first day. You’ll soon notice that when he’s with us he’ll eat all of his lunch, he won’t be so tired and his homework will always be completed. I’ll be at all the conferences and the one he calls when he doesn’t feel well. No, I’m not his mom. I’m his stepmom. Nice to meet you.” 👋🏻⁣
⁣
Back to school means a lot of things, but for stepmoms it means figuring out how you want to show up. Will you be on paperwork? Or removed for the 50th time? 🙄 Will you go to Meet the Teacher and if you do, how will you introduce yourself? Will you get a blank stare because some teachers still don’t know how to accommodate blended families? Do you help buy school clothes, pack their backpack and make the special sign for the first day? ⁣
⁣
Will you feel seen? Included? Appreciated? Valued? Overwhelmed? Anxious? Resentful? ⁣
⁣
I’m sending you all the love and confidence as you navigate another school year. ⁣
Remember: you decide how you want to show up and if you’re doing all the “mom” things, you deserve a seat at the table. You deserve to be seen because your contributions matter.⁣
⁣
YOU MATTER.⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Things may not get easier… but we can get stronger and smarter….⁣
⁣
I shared this mantra in stories and it had such a reaction that it needs a permanent space on the grid. Many of you reached out to share how you’re so tired of waiting for things to settle, calm and feel easier. Ladies, I feel you. ⁣
⁣
The reality is none of that is really in our control. The only thing we have an influence over is how we choose to show up, respond vs react and how we invest in ourselves.⁣
⁣
Here’s what I mean:⁣
Instead of being pissed that once again my husband and are are bickering about BM, I dig deeper and focus on the root; I choose to protect my relationship.⁣
⁣
Instead of feeling resentful about all I do for my SS and feel little reward, I choose to either stop watering the resentment plant or decide where I can step back. ⁣
⁣
Instead of feeling anxious about what’s to come and how to feel prepared, I choose to have faith that whatever comes my partner and I can handle. ⁣
⁣
I may be waiting forever for the changes I want. But I can’t leave my life and happiness on pause. I’m too stubborn for that.⁣
♉️⁣
⁣
Does this resonate?⁣
Where can you find your power and let go of the waiting? ⁣
⁣

Our involvement as stepmoms is not simple…⁣
⁣
We have opinions, values and standards that we carry everywhere. They guide our way through life and give us a sense of security and control…except in stepmotherhood it’s not so easy. Sure…we can communicate our thoughts and opinions. We can say what we “think should” happen until we’re blue in the face, but as the stepmom it does not guarantee our voice will be heard, and listened to. It doesn’t guarantee follow-through and resolve. ⁣
⁣
This is when stepping up can break our hearts…⁣💔
⁣
I WANT to be involved - I like, really give a shit. And it’s not until my husband and I are going head-to-head that I’m reminded maybe I shouldn’t care so much. Not because it’s not important, but because I need to choose my sanity over ensuring something happens the way I think it should. ⁣
⁣
I ask questions like…⁣
“Has that appointment been scheduled yet?”⁣
“She’s been giving him dairy; should we say something?”⁣
“He’s going to miss another practice?”⁣
“His homework didn’t get done.”⁣
⁣
I’m the one noticing. I’m the one that thinks something should happen. I’m the ONLY one that thinks it matters.⁣
⁣
Ladies…I’ve been throwing my hands up a lot more lately. And though there’s some grief in that, I’m seeing it as a release and a gain of freedom. If my mental health is on the line or my relationship with my husband gets contentious, it’s simply not worth it for me.⁣
⁣
Stepping up and stepping back…This is the dance and it’s a hard one to master…⁣
⁣
How are you doing with it? ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

“No one notices when the strong one is tired of being strong.” - Unknown ⁣
⁣
We get told how amazing we are. We’re called “Saints” and hear “I don’t know how you do it.” Our partners see everything we do, but don’t see the invisible load we carry. We make it look effortless, because we ARE badass bitches. ⁣
⁣
But a bitch is tired. ⁣
⁣
I’m tired of biting my tongue. I’m tired of always being the patient one, the more mature one, the organized and structured one. I’m tired of always looking for new ways to improve, be better and grow…. I’m tired of going to therapy because others won’t. 🙄⁣
⁣
If this resonates, let it be a sign. ⁣
Put the heavy shit down. ⁣
Be soft, be vulnerable. ⁣
Ugly cry if you have to. ⁣
You don’t have to be strong all the time. ⁣
Reach out to your partner, a friend… a fellow stepmom, it’s your turn to be held. ⁣
⁣
I see you. ⁣
I feel you. ⁣
I am you. ⁣
⁣

⁣⁣

It’s not co-parenting if she’s only trying to “win”….⁣
⁣
How many of you were sold the idea that your partner and their ex got along just fine, only to observe later that it’s because she treats them like a doormat and your partner is afraid to upset her? Or worse, afraid of her retaliation using the kids? ⁣
⁣
It’s a cycle we didn’t see until we were in it… ⁣
our partners continue to accommodate the unreasonable ex because they’ve always been the accommodater and because high-conflict exes can't differentiate their needs from those of their kids, they will to anything to hurt the other parent and "win." The ex gets aggressive or threatening, our partners get scared and abandon their goals, the ex gets what she wants and the illusion of healthy coparenting lives on. Sound familiar?⁣
⁣
If this resonates I imagine you’re pretty damn frustrated. Not only were you fooled with the smoke and mirrors, but you’re tired of your partner being manipulated and want so badly for them to stand up for themselves, for your stepkids, for you….⁣
⁣
So now what? Recognizing the dynamic is the first step - call it what it is. If it’s dysfunctional, one-sided and lacking respect… it’s not co-parenting. Know that this power dynamic has been established well before you came into the picture and it’s complicated to unravel. Know that you can’t force your partner to step up and change anything until they’ve gained their own awareness and motivation for change. Maybe they need healing. Maybe they need validation and reassurance. The solutions and boundaries might be obvious to you, but be gentle with your partner as they figure out how to move forward. ⁣
⁣
You can’t control anything but your own involvement and reaction. Above all else, be gentle with yourself and establish the boundaries you need for happiness and safety.⁣
⁣

There are the dads who truly walk away and avoid supporting their kids then there are the dads….⁣
⁣
Who are fighting to be part of their kids’ lives.⁣
There are the dads who are spending thousands and thousands for family court only to be told they’re not as important as the mom, they should get less time and the only way they can contribute is by paying child support. There are the dads that have to watch their every move because there’s a mother whose one wish is to push them away and then play victim. ⁣
⁣
My partner is one of those dads. ⁣
⁣
He loves his son and from the moment he was born he had to fight to be part of his life. Years of court dates and thousands of dollars later he was able to gain 50/50 custody - when only every other weekend was offered. To this day, BM will dismiss my husband’s contributions and importance in my SS’s life. WHY? ⁣
⁣
Why are dads minimized and seen as less than? Why do we live in a society that makes it a challenge to be a father, shames a man for not being present and then celebrates the stepdad who decided to “step up”? ⁣
⁣
It’s maddening when we see the love our partners have for their children and it’s not celebrated. It’s heart breaking to watch our partners mourn their children because of alienation. ⁣
⁣
To all the stepmoms who feel this and have partners who are still fighting to be present in their kids’ lives … I see you. ⁣
 ⁣
Dads matter. ⁣

Hanging on by a thread is just baseline now 🤪⁣
⁣
I had a pretty normal and healthy case of anxiety before becoming a stepmom. I had reasonable stressors, I was able to sleep well without a special gummy and I often said things like “meh, no worries.” Bahahahaha fast forward to 9 years of stepmotherhood…I’m full of worries and I have all the gray hair to prove it - though I dye it so you’ll just have to trust me.😉⁣
⁣
Becoming a stepmom has been one of my largest forms of stress. Whether it’s the identity shift, the change in responsibility, the toll it has in my marriage or the ex and all she brings to the table…I have loads to stress about. ⁣
⁣
Can you relate? Do you feel you used to be more “carefree” and now stressed and anxious is your new normal? ⁣
⁣
🧘🏻‍♀️ DEEP BREATHS….⁣
Normalize the reasons why. You have taken on a lot. This is unknown territory. You truly didn’t know what you were signing up for and SO MUCH is out of your control. Feeling stressed and anxious is a normal reaction to an obscene amount of change and/or bullshit. 😬⁣
⁣
Honor those feelings. Take time for yourself. Find what soothes your soul and do a lot of it. ⁣
Better yet… identify what is sucking your energy and stop doing it. ⁣
⁣
Instead of saying “yes” to everything start saying “thanks but no thanks”⁣
Instead of scrolling through the ex’s social media, pick up a book or catch up on your shows. Take ownership of what IS in your control. Some stress may never go away but it doesn’t need to become apart of us. ⁣
⁣
⁣⁣Need some extra support? Girl, let’s talk. Comment “Sessions” and I’ll send you a link to schedule with me. 😘

No hate on my partner but he had me fooled! 😂🫠⁣
⁣
How many of us came into this role not quite understanding the situation? Maybe you thought they didn’t really get along (fair, considering the relationship ended) only to later to find out they can’t even be in the same room together. Maybe you thought they had already agreed on a schedule, where the kids would go to school or how to even communicate. How many are still figuring this all out? 🙃⁣
⁣
Co-parenting is HARD and I gravely minimized the complexities that would still remain even 10 years later. My partner didn’t have shit all figured out and I don’t blame him. But if I had known the dynamics better would I have done things differently? Maybe. 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
 ⁣
What were your assumptions and what were you surprised to learn? ⁣

And wondering why it’s all on you in the first place? 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
With school back in session (we start next week) I am overwhelmed with all the things. I’ve got school supplies and lunch box inventory dancing through my head. I’m checking to see if shoes still fit and questioning where the eff my stepson’s sweatshirts have gone. ⁣
⁣
I snapped at my husband the other day for something “small” but it was BIG to me. I’m not bitter, I don’t hate my family or my husband… I’m just tired and need to share the load. ⁣
⁣⁣
Who else is the keeper of all the things? The  calendar manager and planner? Who else loses sleep because they’re thinking of an email that needs to be written or a uniform that needs to be washed? Who else stares at their partner while they sleep peacefully, wondering what it would be like to have a personal assistant, meal planner and cleaner? 🫠⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We carry a lot and this family/relationship dynamic is not specific to stepmoms. Woman and mothers all over are being told they’re overreacting or too controlling when really we would LOVE some balance and equity in the invisible, but very vital load we carry. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So I see you. And I hope you can have conversations with your partner to feel understood and more supported.
⁣⁣

Why do the littlest things cause such drama?! ⁣⁣

⁣

If we can’t be met at this basic level…then there’s not much left to say…✌🏻⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Whether it’s a family member who dismisses your role because “you’re not the mom”, or a stranger on the internet who feels the need to say “well didn’t you sign up for this?” they clearly don’t get it, and it’s exhausting and hurtful  trying to explain. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Just like anything else, you don’t really know unless you’ve lived it. But it’s important to surround yourself with those who are supportive, despite not experiencing it themselves. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Don’t waste your energy defending your feelings, choices and family to someone who is committed to misunderstanding or judging. This may mean distancing yourself or even losing friendships - but so be it. Make room for those who are truly, authentically rooting for you. ♥️⁣⁣

Just living my childhood dreams over here… 🙄😂⁣
⁣
⁣
In all seriousness though…. Communicating our feelings about being a stepmom to our partners can be challenging. We want to share our inner world and experiences with them so we can feel seen and validated but sometimes it leads to more disconnection and hurt. ⁣
⁣
Especially if anything remotely resembles “you asked for this” comes out of their mouths, it’s ON. 🔥 ⁣
⁣
It takes two to make these convos go well. While we want to be seen and heard, we have to consider that our partners do as well. It’s not easy for them to see us upset and unhappy. They may feel guilty and hopeless in finding a solution. They may be trying to manage or articulate their own feelings about blended life.⁣
Additionally we have our own work to do and our own communication patterns master. ⁣
⁣
A few tips:⁣
First identify if you’re wanting support or a solution before you start the conversation, then lead with connection and empathy. ⁣
⁣
If you need more guidance on these convos comment “LOVE” and I’ll send you my blog post. 😘⁣
⁣
How do you share your struggles with your partner? Do you feel supported? What can be improved? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣

⁣

My guess is yes… they fully expected our partners to just die alone and miserable. 🙄⁣
⁣
I get it, in the throes of a breakup it’s hard to imagine your ex moving on and being happy without you. When kids are involved, it’s difficult to consider another parent figure in their life. ⁣
⁣
But it happens. ⁣
It happens all the time. ⁣
⁣
And when it does the exes seem shocked, offended and betrayed. They’ll minimize the relationship and the role a stepmom may play. You’re forever “just the girlfriend”. She’s the mom. Don’t forget it. The kids have to come first. How dare you have a date night. How dare their ex be happy. How dare they move on and create a life and family. ⁣
⁣
𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘥𝘰𝘶𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘥𝘢𝘳𝘥 𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩 𝘪𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘤𝘬, 𝘳𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵? 𝘉𝘦𝘤𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘦 𝘪𝘧 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘮𝘰𝘷𝘦𝘴 𝘰𝘯 𝘪𝘵’𝘴 𝘰𝘬𝘢𝘺. 🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
With the rate of divorce, you’d think blended families, stepmoms and stepdads would’t be a shocker. But there’s still so much effort and expectations directed at keeping the “nuclear family” intact. ⁣
⁣
Normalize moving forward.⁣
Normalize healthy blended families.⁣
⁣
Who feels the ex expected their partner to just live in misery forever??⁣
⁣

Release yourself from this expectation and burden…✨⁣
⁣
Our hope for peace and happiness makes us feel responsible for making this blended life work. We want organization, communication and boundaries. We want connections with the kids, a relationship with the in-laws, mutual respect from the ex. But what happens when it doesn’t go as planned? What happens when shit blows up and we don’t feel peace? We’re blamed - or we blame ourselves. ⁣
⁣
When I came into the picture the ex blamed me for everything. She was mad a lot and there was always tension. I soon realized  what she was really upset about: she was reacting to boundaries and the control she no longer had over my partner and his home. I may have been there - but that wasn’t my doing. ⁣
⁣
Stepmoms are not solely responsible for making everyone happily blended. Yes, we’re an integral piece of the puzzle, but there are so many other pieces at play and when pieces are broken or missing, well it’s not on us to fix it. ⁣
⁣
You don’t need to carry it all, loves. ⁣
Focus on being authentically you, release the impulse to fix, redistribute the responsibility, and redefine your peace. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

The more we learn about ourselves in this role, the more we need to edit what no longer works for us...⁣
⁣
Like all of you - I didn’t know what I was getting myself into. ⁣
Like many of you - I jumped right into a parenting role and got way in over my head. ⁣
I had little to no boundaries, and my expectations were naive. I didn’t know what I was “allowed” to speak up about. I didn’t know where I fit. So I went along with everything, I was always trying to prove myself...and it worked, until it didn’t. ⁣
⁣
Anxiety. Depression. Resentment. Anger. Hopelessness.... you get the idea. By the time I was carrying all that negativity, my partner had gotten real comfortable with me being so “cool” and “go-with-the-flow”. Whoops. My mistake. ⁣
⁣
I needed to edit how I was showing up for him and my SS. I needed to voice my boundaries and expectations. I needed to show that I wasn’t just a casual addition to their already established family...I needed to be part of forming a new family. I needed to redefine what being a stepmom meant to ME, and not just embody what was assumed of me. ⁣
⁣
We can’t be held to who we were before we knew who we are (oh the things I would tell the young stepmom me😂). We have to be given the space to edit what is no longer serving us. ⁣
⁣
How have you changed from when you first took on this role? What have you had to edit?⁣
⁣⁣⁣

You’ll never figure her out… don’t even go there. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
When we ask ourselves, “why can’t she just be a mom?” Or “How could she do that/or not do that to her kids?” … the answer is simple: she isn’t you. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I feel I do a lot of things that his mom SHOULD being doing. I have the hard conversations with him. I make sure his homework is complete and he has clothes that fit. I find myself asking “Why wouldn’t she prepare him better? How could she do this to him?” It’s not that I don’t want to be doing these things; I’m showing up the only way I know how. But maybe … so is she. I have to remind myself she isn’t me. She doesn’t think like I do. She doesn’t love the way I do.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I can be the loving support for my SS and that’s what matters. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I know it’s hard, mama’s. I know it’s infuriating to be doing so much of the “mom” things, with little appreciation or recognition. I know you wonder why you’re the one talking about the hard shit. I know you want to step back, parent less, but you can’t because she won’t step up. But try and reframe: damn those kids are lucky to have you. ♥️⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We can’t make the ex be better. We can’t wait for her to pay attention, show interest or give a shit about what their kid actually needs; We may be waiting forever. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
She can’t live up to your standards because she isn’t you…and that’s your power. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
If you need more reminders like this,⁣
Consider taking my Overcoming The Mama Drama workshop. 😘We’ll evict her from your head…together. Comment “EVICT” for more info! ⁣

You know who has the biggest critique of a stepmom??⁣
⁣
People who aren’t stepmoms. 😑⁣
⁣
I liken it to people watching the Olympics. An Olympic Athlete tumbles on the ice or misses a hit and some asshole on their couch yells, “C’mon! It’s not that hard!”⁣… Bitch, you get on the ice and do it - then we’ll talk. It ain’t easy!⁣
⁣
But even if we know our feelings and experiences are real, we’re vulnerable to their opinions aren’t we? We don’t want to be evil. We don’t always know what’s “right”. We wonder if we’re overreacting. We question ourselves…⁣
⁣
“Can I be a stepmom if I’m not married?” ⁣
“Am I awful because I don’t love my stepkid?”⁣
⁣
Questions like this are based on expectations placed on stepmoms. Expectations that we don’t have to conform to. I have this belief that stepmoms get to dictate how they show up in their relationships and homes - radical, right?⁣
There’s a million ways to be a stepmom and only the stepmom can decide what’s best for her and her family. Love your stepkid - or don’t. Be called “mom” - or don’t.  Be super involved - or don’t. ⁣
⁣
You do you, boo. ⁣
✨swipe for bonus!

Seems like a pretty obvious fact but it’s not 😂🤦🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
Over the weekend I shared on stories about my daughter’s birthday party. We had all the family in attendance which incouded my husband’s mom, dad and stepmom. Who remembers Tina from the podcast?! 💕My husband admitted he was a little anxious about having all his parents together - they haven’t been around one another since our wedding 8 years ago. Tina vocalized a little of her own feelings “well this should be fun. I’ll bring the 🍿” were her exact words. 😂 ⁣
⁣
It was all just a reminder about how we’ll all still have to come together even when our step kids are grown. There will be graduations and weddings and baby showers and birthday parties. Yay! But also 😩 because the thought of sitting around a kitchen island (my husband’s mom and stepmom over the weekend) and chatting just feels too much right now. ⁣
⁣
My hope is that time will heal and we’ll move on from the conflict. We won’t be parenting together anymore and it’s our job to release the past. Again.. that’s my hope. 😂⁣
⁣
How does this reality make you feel? ⁣
And stepmoms who have frown stepkids.. what is the dynamic like for you? ⁣

We don’t get a break… just like “real moms”….⁣
⁣⁣
Real talk: we had a hard week with my stepson. Some of it is his pre-teen attitude. Some of it is his ADHD. New routine. New school. New expectations. Some of it is the blatant issues we have with the other house and how he’s being raised. Regardless, we struggled. He’s back to his mom tomorrow and while I feel the sense of physical relief that I get a break - my mind doesn’t shut up. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I’m thinking about an email we have to write. ⁣⁣
I’m thinking of how I should have handled that conversation differently. I’m future tripping and feeling anxious about something that may or may not happen. I’m planning, prepping and worrying. ⁣⁣
⁣
I have the tools to disengage and I know what to do for myself when I feel this way. But my point here is to simply acknowledge to myself and to others that this feeling is real and valid. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I hope you know you’re an amazing stepmom. ⁣⁣
I hope you know you’re not alone in carrying that mental load. I hope you know it’s okay if you’re exhausted. ⁣⁣
⁣
You’re carrying the unique load of a stepmom.⁣
You’ve inherited the emotional load of a mother. ⁣
Your emotions are real. ⁣
⁣⁣
Sit down. ⁣⁣
Take a breath. ⁣⁣
You’re okay. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Be loud, you’re not alone, we’re in this together….⁣
⁣
I didn’t know being a stepmom would come with so many challenges. Met a guy with a kid? Cool! Kids are fun! Have an ex? We all do. NBD. Oh my sweet naive soul… 😂⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I thought the challenges I was facing and the feelings I was having made me a bad person. I thought that it meant we were doomed and I was obviously not cut out for this stepmom gig. But I was also deeply in love with my guy, and I so badly wanted the family we were creating. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I had to learn and accept that both can be true. You can be annoyed and irritated, sad and grieving… but still hold joy and want to show up every day for the family you love. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You can feel it all and still be right where you’re meant to be. ♥️⁣⁣

There’s freedom in adjusting expectations…⁣
⁣
As stepmoms we are in the middle of two other parents with their own styles of parenting. Things can get complicated when you don’t agree with your partner’s parenting style. And it can get really frustrating when you’re up against the differences from the other home. ⁣
⁣
“I wouldn’t handle it that way.” ⁣
⁣
“I would never do that to my own kid.” ⁣
⁣
Ever take your stepkids somewhere and feel embarrassed by their behavior? “That’s not on me…their mom let’s them get away with everything.” ⁣
⁣
We are actively participating in the parenting but feel we have to tiptoe around sharing our thoughts, opinions or ideas. We don’t want to criticize or throw gas on the high conflict fire. We want to parent our stepkids like they’re “our own” but how much control or influence do we really have? ⁣
⁣
There is freedom in letting go of the comparison. I have been more successful in having conversations with my partner about our differences and coming to a compromise than getting frustrated that he’s doing things differently than I would. I have been happier accepting I have no control over how my SS’s mom parents and content knowing I have some (albeit minor) influence when he’s in our home.⁣
⁣
But honestly….Sometimes your biggest effort of self care may be saying, “You two can figure this one out.” 🍿⁣
⁣
⁣🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

Ugh...let’s talk about when our partners get defensive.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I get it. They love their kids and they don’t like hearing anything negative or even 𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘤𝘦𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘥 as negative. Then there’s the double standard that they can say anything they want but if we chime in and agree, we’re monsters. 🤦🏻‍♀️ Regardless, we deserve to have a voice and a space to share our feelings and concerns...but it’s up to US to do it in a way we’ll be heard. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
The way we communicate could make or break us. Saying, “I’ve had a hard day with Emily. Can I share some feelings with you?” is a lot different than, “Emily was such a brat today!” Both may be true, but only one will encourage your partner to really hear you. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
As stepmoms we have a lot of feelings, often overwhelming and bubbling over. The worst scenario is when these feelings cause a divide between you and your partner. We have to be honest and see where we contribute to the problems we so deeply hate. Damn, being a stepmom is complicated.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Can you relate? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

⁣
There’s a lot of vulnerability in really speaking about your journey as a stepmom. ⁣⁣⁣

If you’ve been to court - you know the value of DOCUMENTATION. Even if you don’t have a high conflict situation, it’s still super beneficial to be organized and document things like changes in the schedule, emails and text messages. ⁣

🙋🏻‍♀️Raise your hand if the ex has ever said: ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“I’m not parenting with HER, I’m parenting with you.” Or “She’s not the parent/mom.”⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
These exes barely want to co-parent at all, let alone with YOU. They have little to no choice but to share custody, decisions and responsibilities with your partner and they're mad about it so they’ll drag you through hell doing it. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
If the ex has little to no respect for the other parent to their kid(s) they will have a really hard time developing respect for you. They didn’t choose you, and they’ll try and dictate how much they’ll allow you into the parenting role.⁣⁣⁣
Keyword: try.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
So here’s your weekly reminder to stop trying to understand why she doesn’t like you. Why she can’t just accept you. Why she can’t get over it. Why she still holds a grudge. It’s not about you. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Don’t search for her acceptance or validation, babes. She’s not the keeper of that. You are.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣

Hey partners... I’m talking to you...👋🏻⁣
⁣
I know you didn’t expect your life to be like this either. I know you’re carrying hurt, resentment and grief too. But that woman you chose has made a commitment for your future together and she needs your help to make it what you all deserve. ⁣
⁣
Your partner... she needs you to let go of the past and make room for your hopes, dreams, traditions and love. She needs your support and encouragement. She needs to hear that while she may not be the first, you’re committed to making her the last. She needs you to stand up for her, her role and your family. It may feel like a lot. But look at everything she does for you...your children...isn’t she worth it? ⁣
⁣
You have something beautiful and it’s yours if you nurture it. 💕⁣
⁣
Also...while I have you... maybe plan a date night or something? Make her feel special. 😘
⁣
Stepmoms... I love you. 😘⁣

I know this because… I’m a stepmom too. ⁣

We’re stepmoms and we’re also human…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We have normal people stressors like work, bills, relationships, family dynamics and health. ⁣⁣
When we’re managing stress we also have the added weight of being a stepmom… dealing with a transition day, the ex or court; sometimes it feels like too much. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A stepmom who loses a pet may not want to have to feel “on” when their stepkid comes home.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A stepmom who’s navigating fertility may not have the energy to attend a baseball game. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A stepmom who is overwhelmed with work, missing their parent or isn’t feeling well… just wants to tend to those needs and not their stepparent responsibilities. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In any of these situations you’re also carrying the pressure to show up, the guilt of not being present, the needs of your partner or your stepkid(s). Sometimes it feels like we can’t just be human, have a bad day or be in a grumpy mood. ⁣Sometimes you don’t want to have to also think about how to explain it to your stepkid(s) or what the ex might have to say. ⁣
⁣
𝘐𝘧 𝘐’𝘮 𝘴𝘪𝘤𝘬 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘶𝘱𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘪𝘳𝘴 𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘥𝘢𝘺, 𝘸𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘮𝘺 𝘚𝘚 𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘮? 𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘸𝘪𝘭𝘭 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘬? ⁣
⁣⁣
Can you relate??⁣⁣
Your feelings are valid. ⁣⁣
You deserve the grace of tending to the other things weighing on you. ⁣⁣
You can have bad days.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I encourage you to share these feelings with your partner. Your experience is important and so are your needs. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Take time for you.⁣⁣
The YOU that is so much more than a stepmom.⁣⁣
⁣⁣

Always remember the double standards, babes...⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣
Yesterday was tough! My stepson does this cute little thing when he’s bored where he just follows me around everywhere in hopes I’ll entertain him. WTF. At one point I got away and sat quietly to myself… it lasted 3 mins before he found me and I literally said, “dude, I’m literally trying to hide from you. Go find something to do.”🤦🏻‍♀️ #imanassholebecause right??!! ⁣
⁣
Who also finds themselves irritated by the kids? ⁣
⁣
Would you say you hold yourself to a higher standard than the other parents? Would you say others put more pressure or expectations on you than they do your partner or the ex? Do you judge yourself or feel guilty for the feelings you’re having? ⁣⁣
⁣
I felt bad for a moment and then reminded myself that kids needs to be bored sometimes and it’s not my responsibility to be entertaining him all the time. ⁣
⁣⁣
Notice the double standards and give yourself some grace. It’s normal to be irritated with your kids. It’s normal to want alone time with your partner. It’s normal to want time to yourself. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A Reminder: Some of the things we feel aren’t stepmom related - they’re just PARENTING related. So congrats, you’re in the club. 😘⁣⁣

I can love my family, but also admit I’m struggling...⁣🤷🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣⁣
I’m not a “good vibes only” type of stepmom. I have found I am the least effective when I’m pretending everything is all 🌈🌈 and 🦋🦋. I’m more of a “this gig can be real 💩 sometimes” kind of stepmom and saying/hearing “just stay positive” or “look on the bright side.” doesn’t work for me. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We have to protect ourselves from the toxic positivity masquerading as encouragement, support or role models. If it’s making you feel shame, guilt or like you have to silence your real feelings - it’s not serving you.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Your feelings are real, valid, and important, and they can provide information and help you see things about a situation that you need to work to change. There’s power in being an authentic hot mess. 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
If we want our 💩 to turn into 🌈 we need to first step in it and acknowledge it’s there. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Who has whiplash from all the inconsistencies? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
She communicates effectively one day, but then goes silent the next. She’s super mom when it’s convenient, then switches to “you take care of it” when it’s not. She follows through, respects boundaries and may even be accepting of the stepmom…Sometimes she’s just quiet and content …then the full moon comes and she’s back to her HC self. 🎢 ⁣
⁣
We’ve all felt it at some point - that feeling of hope that things are getting better, but we’re holding our breath waiting for the next shift.⁣
So what do you do? ⁣
⁣
Remain consistent. Wherever she’s at on her rollercoaster, you remain the same. Follow the custody order. Maintain your boundaries. Focus on the kids. Be “business respectful” regardless of what she’s presenting as. Keep your responses and affect the same. Bore her. ⁣
⁣
Protect your nervous system. When the inconsistencies are based on her own convenience, relationship status or is she wakes up and chooses evil it is never intentional or long lasting growth. ⁣
⁣
Does this resonate? ⁣
How do you manage the inconsistencies? ⁣
How do you bore her?⁣
⁣⁣

We may have “signed up for this” but we have expectations for our partners too…⁣
⁣
Shoutout to all the partners who listen to us when we’re frustrated, overwhelmed, confused or battling a broken heart. Thank you to all the partners who acknowledge the difficulties of this stepmom role and are our landing place for comfort, belonging and the feeling of “home”. Thank you to all the partners who validate what we’re feeling without judgment. The partners who help facilitate the relationships with the stepkids and protect us from the barbs of the ex. They carry the load of their own baggage and celebrate the woman who came into their life; loving her however she wants to show up, because she didn’t know what the hell she was getting into. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Of course, this type of partnership doesn’t happen overnight. It does take trial and error, hard conversations and a commitment to growth to get to that space. But at the core of any healthy relationship is respect and the willingness to be both vulnerable and influenced.⁣
⁣
We did not commit to our partners to be left feeling alone, misunderstood and made to question our own realities. We are not in these relationships to be silent about the things that matter to us or made to feel like the problem. We deserve better. ⁣
⁣
So, sweet stepmoms. My hope for you is you have the supportive and loving partner you deserve. Give them some extra love today. And if you find yourself in the dark and have no partner to light your way, I hope you have the courage to light your own torch and walk away from what’s no longer good for you. ⁣
⁣
You’re a badass, a QUEEN and you deserve to feel like it everyday. 🔥⁣

Being the bigger person suuuuccckkksss….⁣
⁣
She disrespects you. Dismisses you. Maybe she outwardly tells the kids you’re not a parent and to not listen to you. You’re “just the girlfriend” and need to know your part. She crosses boundaries, is committed to creating chaos and is someone you would EVER want to be associated with…⁣

⁣
You’re stuck swallowing all the things you’d like to say. You hate it. It sucks. ⁣
It’s exhausting being the bigger person all the time but damn…we can’t let her turn us into someone we’re not. ⁣
⁣
You’re an amazing stepmom and I’m screaming “wtf” with you.⁣

Being a stepmom has been the most confusing role I’ve ever held….⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Among all the struggles, the relationship with my stepson has been one of my biggest sources of confusion. Am I connecting enough? Am I parenting too much? Is he comparing me to his mom? Am I the one comparing? How am I showing up and is it aligned with how I truly want to show up? How will he talk about me when he’s older? “My stepmom was…”⁣⁣⁣
I carry these thoughts with me always…and it’s exhausting. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
I know I need to be more gentle with myself. The way I show up is enough. It may not be easy and it’s not always from a place of innate love…but he sees what I do everyday. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Stepmoms, my message to you is this: ⁣⁣⁣
Our stepkids have made an impact on our hearts, and us on theirs. It may not be biological or even love, but it matters and it’s special all on its own. Notice the small moments and let it quiet your anxieties and worries. Store it away for a rainy day. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Without a doubt, stepmom … you are making an impact just by being you. 🌹⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣

It’s a really slippery and confusing slope ladies…⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
We support our partners by showing up for them and kids. We cook meals, do laundry, wipe tears and butts, show up to practices and games and carry all the emotional labor moms around the globe carry. Some of us are the fixers and the buffers. We respond to emails from the ex, handle transitions, manage the schedules all because we’re “better at it”. ⁣
⁣
But how does this make us feel? How are we being impacted by being supportive and showing up? ⁣
⁣
The truth is…a lot of our supportive efforts are enabling our partners from growing as parents and learning how to manage the relationship with their ex. Our involvement can feel great, but it can also lead to feelings of burnout and resentment. ⁣
⁣
Call it what it is. Ask yourself how your support is benefiting everyone - including you. Do you feel appreciated or taken for granted? Check in with yourself and adjust when you realize you’re doing things you don’t want to do - are you “shoulding” on yourself? Have the hard conversations with your partner and invite them to start showing up differently. ⁣
⁣
“Support” is not doing everything so your partner isn’t inconvenienced by being a parent or dealing with the ex. ⁣
“Involved” is not saying “yes” to everything only to feel depleted, anxious and resentful. ⁣
⁣
Balance is a hard goal to achieve - but where’s your first step? ⁣Need some help getting started, comment “support” and I’ll DM you. 😘
⁣

Just out of curiosity … who feels this way? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣
⁣
Yes… definitely me. And my husband knows it too. He’ll fully admit it. My life before taking on this stepmom life was simplistic. I worried about myself. Things were more in my control. If someone was rude or didn’t like me… girl, bye. ⁣
⁣
This life has shook me up in ways I couldn’t have predicted. While I’m dealing with someone who hates my guts, my husband has a partner and isn’t doing it all alone. While I’m up late worrying about x,y and z… my husband sleeps peacefully knowing his partner is a planner and has shit handled. While I’m questioning and contemplating my role, existence and every move I make… my husband just… LIVES?! 😧⁣
⁣
Sometimes it’s hard to see the benefits of being a stepmom when WE are the biggest benefit. If you can relate, I see you. ⁣
⁣
I encourage you to honor these feelings and know it’s okay to feel them. If you feel you’re the one who came with a carry-on but carrying everyone else’s baggage…. Find ways to adjust. How can your partner support you? What would make you feel different? ⁣
⁣
You deserve to feel the benefits this role can bring, not just the sacrifices. ⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Did anyone grow up wanting to be a stepmom? 🤔⁣⁣
⁣⁣
My teenage self would probably look at me now and be proud…and also confused because WTF? 😂 You mean you didn’t end up riding motorcycles and marrying Rider Strong from Boy Meets World? I’ve dated myself here - but whatever. 🤪⁣⁣
⁣⁣
My point is - being a stepmom is not something we grow up thinking of becoming. Especially when the media has done such a great job of teaching us how amazing stepmoms are - Parent Trap … eeek. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
With that said - we all fell in love and consequently fell into this role that has become a part of our identity. It’s not all glitter and rainbows, but I wanted to remind you to notice the good that’s come with the unexpected. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I love my partner. Like REALLY love him in a gross-stop-get-a-room kind of way. I love the life we’ve built and are continuing to build together. I love that I can be part of my stepson’s life, and I’m confident in saying I’m in it with purpose. I didn’t ask for this life - but this life was meant for me - tough shit and all. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

There are amazing stepmoms EVERYWHERE…⁣
⁣
If a stepmom posts about how she shows up for their stepkid there are two types of commenters. The ones who say “that’s nice but you’re not the mom” and those who say “you’re amazing! I wish all stepmoms were like you!” Both comments are wildly confused. But let’s focus on the second one…⁣
⁣
MOST stepmoms are amazing, thoughtful, loving, warm and kind. They don’t carry around poison apples, they aren’t trying to send the kids off to boarding school, they aren’t hateful and evil. They show up, give a shit and are trying to carve out space in their family. ⁣
⁣
But people see what they want to see and attach their own shit to our story. For whatever reason, people will assume the worst in us until proven otherwise. They think amazing stepmoms are an exception, not the rule. ⁣
⁣
So here are some comments I would drop on your stepmom post…⁣
“You’re an amazing stepmom”⁣
“I love how you show up for your family.”⁣
“I can see how much you care.” ⁣
“You are so valued and important.” ⁣
“Stepmoms are f*cking amazing and though I know it’s hard you’re killing it.” 😉⁣
⁣
What comments would you like to see? ⁣
How can we start responding to the wildly dumb ones? 😂⁣
⁣

⁣
You could be surrounded by others throughout the day and still experience a deep and pervasive loneliness. Maybe you feel a lack of connection with your partner. ⁣
Maybe you feel left out within your blended family. Maybe you’re not feeling connected to your stepkid(s). ⁣
⁣
Or maybe it’s none of that...and the deepest loneliness is felt because you feel you can’t talk about the things weighing heavy on you...⁣
⁣
Your partner may not understand your feelings, so you’ve stopped sharing. ⁣
Your parents don’t understand why you “put up with it”.⁣
And your friends...aren’t stepmoms and just think your life is chaos and are tired of the “gossip.” ⁣
⁣
If any of this resonates with you...if you’re feeling isolated in your own heart and mind...⁣
know you’re among a community of others like you. ⁣

Oh, the magic we don’t quite get to experience, eh? 😬 ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
What is control? You mean there’s couples that can just schedule their lives and not have to consider a whole other home? What would it be like to not have to second guess every decision I make and how I show up in my stepson’s life? What would it feel like to walk around my home and not fear my SS will relay intel to his mom? ⁣
⁣
Magical thinking, right? 🦄⁣
⁣
I will say it has gotten better over time...⁣it really has. Not because my circumstances have changed, but because I have. I’ve gotten more confident, I’ve dug deep and healed because when there’s a lot we can’t control, it pushes us to acceptance or finding other ways of influence. We may feel like strangers or outsiders in our own homes, but we have to explore those feelings, identify what we need  and communicate with our partners. ⁣⁣
⁣
If you need help with this - reach out to me. Get some support, mama. ⁣
⁣⁣
The hard stuff is hard, but our lives as stepmoms can still be magical. ✨ ⁣⁣

It’s a lot easier to blame us, than to look in the mirror.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We’re always the villain. We’re always the reason for the conflict and chaos. If only we didn’t fall in love. If only the kids didn’t like us. If only we didn’t give a shit. How dare we want to have a happy home and family. But we’re screwed either way. If we weren’t committed and loving, she’d be mad at that too. 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s not about the stepmom. It’s about the ex’s unresolved emotions. Her grief. Her loss. Her resentment. Her insecurities. Knowing this does 3 things: ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
1) It makes space for compassion and empathy. Yea, I know it’s fucking hard. Especially when she’s a nightmare. But...woman to woman...we can put ourselves in her shoes and though we KNOW we’d handle it differently, we can appreciate the struggle. Also, ⁣⁣
2) It releases us from taking shit so personal. She’s going to be mad at whoever is standing next to her ex, caring for her kids. You’ve done nothing to deserve what she’s been dishing out - that’s all on her. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣3) It makes us reflect on our own high conflict tendencies - yes we have them. When she goes low, we have an opportunity to check ourselves and make sure we aren’t contributing. If you aren’t - 👏🏼then you can brush it off as a HER problem, not a YOU problem. ⁣

🥳New Episode! ⁣
⁣
I welcome Megan from the High Conflict Institute to chat about co-parenting with someone who operates with a repetitive pattern of high conflict. In order to be effective, we have to understand how a high conflict person thinks - so how do they? How do you flip the script to start interacting with them differently? Megan shares some great tools on how to change the way you communicate in your dynamic. Oh and a bonus... she's a stepmom! What would she have done differently? What has helped her stay grounded in who she is? If you're managing high conflict, grab your partner and listen in! ⁣
⁣
About My Guest: ⁣
Megan Hunter, MBA, is co-founder and CEO of the High Conflict Institute along with author and speaker, Bill Eddy, LCSW, Esq. who developed the high-conflict personality theory. Megan developed the concept of the Institute after eight years in policy, legislation and judicial training with the Arizona Supreme Court, Administrative Office of the Courts and five years with the Dawes County Attorney’s Office in Nebraska. She is the author and/or co-author of several books on high conflict interactions and co-host of the podcast It’s All Your Fault!⁣

Even if you have a good relationship with the ex, interactions or social gatherings may cause some pit sweat. 😂 If you have a high conflict situation - well that’s a whole different level of anxiety. ⁣⁣

I have worked with many new stepmoms who stepped into an already established tradition of joint holidays. ⁣⁣
To those who do joint holidays - what’s that like 👀. Who had to stop the joint stuff and create your own traditions? Who’s still trying to create some separation? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Wherever you’re at on the spectrum - sending love, strength and peace. ⁣⁣

The transition was fast and furious 🥴😂⁣
⁣
I was living alone, and eating charcuterie in front of my favorite show every night. I was HAPPY. Then I met my person, his child and before I knew it I was cooking nuggets and trying to teach a 3yo table manners. I was very HAPPY but my cute little purse transitioned into a big bag of snacks and toys and all of a sudden there were crumbs everywhere… who had I become?! ⁣
⁣
For many of us this is just part of our journey. This is what happens when we are eager,⁣ committed and excited to be giving our hearts to our new relationship. I think what many of us want though is to be seen for this change and what feels like a major sacrifice. That just because we’re struggling, doesn’t mean we aren’t capable. We want our partners to acknowledge that maybe these changes aren’t coming easy and to hold some grace as we figure out this new identity. We need our partners to still support and nurture the woman they met, her dreams and her priorities  because they still matter. ⁣
⁣
The acts of being a stepparent can feel like it happens overnight, but our hearts need some time to catch up. 💓Even with great gain there can be grief. ⁣
⁣
Who can relate? What drastic shifts did you/are you experiencing? What do you want your partner to acknowledge? ⁣

My existence pisses her off and I think that’s funny 🤷🏻‍♀️⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Of course we want to please everyone. We want our partners happy, our stepkids…we’re even hoping to please our in-laws and family friends. If you’re like me, you learned pretty quick that it’s impossible to please everyone. Y’all need to take turns. 😂⁣⁣
⁣⁣
My biggest lesson was the ex. In the beginning I was wildly empathetic, friendly and agreeable. I didn’t show up to things, I gave the “real parents” space..she still wasn’t happy. I know now it doesn’t matter what I do - she’s committed to being pissed. She must be exhausted, really. And it’s all on her. It doesn’t have to be this way. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So I do what’s best for me, and my family. I remain respectful and empathetic, but I’m not a doormat and I have boundaries. She especially hates that. 😂⁣⁣
⁣⁣
You can’t please everyone. Be confident in who you are and what you provide to your family. And when they get mad at the pettiest things, remember to laugh. 😬⁣⁣

I’m not evil….but I am human. ♥️⁣
⁣
It all just gets to be too much sometimes. Whether it’s the ex making decisions that impact our home, my partner getting frustrated and stressed, or direct attacks on me… it’s hard to show up for my stepson with energy and a smile. I know that’s what he deserves and damn do I try… but it’s tiring, you know? ⁣
⁣
Sometimes our stepkids embody their other parent. They talk like them, look like them (my case) and are sometimes even disrespectful like them and it feels like the ex is living in your home too. It can feel confusing and even unsafe at times. ⁣
⁣
“They’re just kids” is often the reminder. As if that’s supposed to wash away all these feelings. Yes. They ARE just kids and it’s our responsibility to process and do our own inner work so we can show up for them, shield them from what isn’t theirs to carry - but sometimes I just want to sit in the suck for a moment and be acknowledged that THIS is not how I want to be spending my energy.⁣
⁣
If this resonates… you’re not alone and I invite you to sit with me and give yourself some grace. The fact that this is difficult for you makes you a good stepmom; it makes you human. We have to first honor our feelings so we can tend to them in the way we deserve. The way our family deserves. ⁣
⁣
I see you, stepmom. ⁣
I am you. ⁣
⁣

Resentment breeds in a lot of different ways…⁣
⁣
⁣
One of the biggest sources of resentment for me is when I’m doing things I truly don’t want to do, or I feel deeply taken advantage of. ⁣
⁣
In my early days of stepmotherhood I was saying “yes” to everything because I felt like I should. I felt I had to prove myself. I needed to show my then boyfriend that I was great with kids, a “mom” type, that I was the dream girl he’d been searching for. 💁🏻‍♀️ I mean, I am that girl but like, I didn’t have to lose myself in the process. I also felt the need to show the ex that I was a good person, kind and thoughtful. That I was worthy of respect and understanding… hahhahaha oh silly, optimistic me. ⁣😂
⁣
Burnout and resentment eventually found me and I had to assess how I was choosing to show up. I had to let go of the internal pressure and really advocate for what I wanted from the relationship - not just how I could contribute. ⁣I had to start saying “thank you, but no” and realize that now matter how awesome I am the ex does not care. If I was going to be in this for the long haul - I had to start showing up for me, not for acceptance. 
⁣
When we find ourselves feeling resentful it’s a signal to look inward and assess how we’ve contributed and where we need to adjust. ⁣
In a role where it’s easy to lose yourself we have to be intentional about remaining authentic to our wants and needs; it’s our damn lifeline. ⁣
⁣
Any of this resonating? Who needs to reassess? ⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

We all made a choice, right? The moment we learned our partner’s had a kid (or plural) we could have said, “yea, not for me.” But we didn’t. Our hearts wanted the person in front of us, or at least our minds wanted to give it a shot. ⁣
⁣
I wasn’t looking for a family when I met my partner. I was barely looking for a boyfriend. 😂 But I got swept away and as shit started getting real I continued to make that decision over and over again: “Is this for me? Can I do it?” I love my husband and he is what I always come back to. ⁣

⁣
We stumbled upon someone wonderful and got a whole lot more than we bargained for…⁣

Okay…so hear me out…😬⁣
⁣
I fell in love and became a stepparent by proxy. I in no way was looking to take on diapers, tantrums and a custody schedule. ⁣
I took on all those things because I wanted to be with my partner and he just so happened to come with a cute-little-sticky-fingered three year old. The relationship I have with my husband will always be the priority - yes, even over the kids. ⁣
⁣
There is this assumption that just because children are already present - all romance goes out the window. Ummm, no. Just because I’m a stepmom doesn’t mean I want to sacrifice my date nights and kid-free vacations.⁣
⁣
Stepmoms don’t get the life-before-kids-experience. We’re just expected to plop right into family mode and not have any yearning for what “traditional” couples have. We are labeled selfish if we want time away from the kids. We’re told “you knew what you signed up for” (we didn’t) when we grieve the experiences we’ll never have. ⁣
⁣
Nope. I won’t have it. ⁣
Stepmoms….⁣
Advocate for the life you want and deserve. ⁣
I believe you can have it all. ⁣
You can be a stepmom, AND get date nights with your person. You can be a stepmom AND have romantic kid-free vacations. You can be a stepmom AND make your relationship a priority. ⁣
⁣
If your partner struggles with this - ask them⁣
what’s holding them back. Is it guilt? Do they have unsaid expectations? Do they just need to hear your needs communicated differently? ⁣
⁣
You are a partner first and a stepmom second…. Radical, I know. 😘⁣
⁣
🖤⁣⁣⁣

⁣
⁣
As stepmoms, we can often feel like outsiders as we step into an "already established family", but we have to change the belief that there's only one way to "family". What have they done to form their own unique family unit? Listen in! ⁣
⁣
If you're looking for a book to help your stepkid's understand how a stepmom can bring positivity to the family, check out Brent's ⁣
debut children’s book, ⁠Opposititis: A Ridiculous Family Love Story ⁠is a silly heartwarming story for 4- to 9-year-olds and their families. Comment BOOK and I’ll send you the link! ⁣
⁣
About My Guest: ⁣
Brent Crandal, PhD, is an author, child and family psychologist, and researcher. He also provides psychotherapy in San Diego and co-authored a widely adopted guide for therapists, Modular CBT for Children and Adolescents with Depression. He enjoys training professionals and teaching in higher education (e.g., UCSD, SDSU, and USD).⁣

Many of us operate in the belief that if we….⁣
⁣
can plan it, predict it, prepare and get ahead of it… we can control the outcomes and protect what we value most. ⁣
⁣
We lay in bed at night wondering how or when she’ll respond to that email. We try and foresee what she’ll do next to ruin the happiness in your home. You’ll anxiously talk to your partner about what you’re anticipating and hoping for validation and reassurance only to be told “you’re overthinking”. ⁣
⁣
They’re not wrong. You are. But it’s not that simple. ⁣
⁣
When we are trying to protect our home and happiness how can we not feel on guard? We want to feel prepared and in control….⁣
⁣
CONTROL. There’s the word that I latch on to. What can I can control? What power am I granting her as I lay awake at night? Is “feeling prepared” more valuable than enjoying an evening with my partner? What do I really have control over? ⁣
⁣
Overthinking is going to happen. Notice where it’s coming from and what your core need is. Ask if it’s in within your control. Soothe yourself in saying “whatever happens…we’ll handle it.” Take your power back. ⁣
⁣
Who’s overthinking right now? ⁣
What’s your core need? ⁣
 ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣

How do you answer when a friend asks, “how are you?” Or..⁣
⁣
⁣
“What’s new?”⁣
⁣
For me, I’ve gotten really skilled at compartmentalizing my life. Do I respond with the full story? Do I share how I’m struggling with my stepson’s pre-teen attitude? Do I vent about the ex’s latest email and what I’m anxious about? How real do I get about such a huge part of my life? ⁣
⁣
Sometimes I’ll just talk about work, or my daughter. Sometimes I’ll just share about upcoming plans or give a surface level, “I’m good! Super busy!” ⁣
⁣
There are some friends who I’ll share it all with. There are also friends who I find myself wanting to share more, but can see their eyes widen as I share the drama 😳 or I feel insecure about their judgement… “she’s an evil stepmom”. ⁣
⁣
Stepmotherhood can feel lonely for all these reasons. Saying our stories out loud to people who don’t understand can make us feel crazy. ⁣
Honestly, this is why this platform was created. ⁣
We need our safe space. Our mental health requires it. ⁣
⁣
Does this resonate for you? How do your non-stepmom friends understand and support you? Do you also feel you filter some of what you share? ⁣
⁣
I hope you have the true friendships that can help you through this life… and remember if you need a stepmom friend, reach out to me and get connected. Comment FRIEND and I’ll DM you. 🫶🏻⁣
⁣

Blended life impacts my marriage and I hate it…😒⁣
⁣
Whether it’s feeling misunderstood or unsupported in my role….the stress of a custody schedule, navigating the relationship with my stepson, parenting style differences, or the inevitable and unavoidable chaos from the ex… my husband and I have argued about it all. ⁣
⁣
Nothing makes me feel more disconnected from my partner than arguing about this stuff. Nothing makes me feel more resentful than thinking our marriage would be different if this blended dynamic didn't exist. What would it be like? I get sad thinking about how much happier we would be…⁣
⁣
Anyone else? ⁣
⁣
This is the grief I carry and I have to acknowledge it to move through it. This is my source of resentment, but I have to find acceptance that this is my reality. Because at the end of the day, I will choose my husband over and over again. My husband and I may have disagreements about blended family shit, but it’s on us to protect our marriage and home from the chaos. Daydreaming about a life I’ll never have prevents me from celebrating what we’ve created together. I HAVE to remember this…⁣
⁣
Who needs this reminder too? ⁣
How has your relationship been impacted by blended life? How has it made you stronger? ⁣

I needed a pep talk and this is what I came up with…⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Stepmoms make sacrifices everyday to be with the person they love. Stepmoms are the most⁣⁣
thoughtful and considerate group of women I’ve ever known or been apart of - despite what the media might portray. Stepmoms are constantly in positions of choosing what’s best for their partner, their stepkids or overall family, even at the sacrifice of what’s best for them. We carry complicated emotions but our main hope is our family will benefit - that we’ll see the reward. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
If you’ve been following for a bit you know my stepson’s mom is making choices that would impact our schedule. My husband and I have been put in the position of possibly taking my stepson full-time, instead of her tossing him to sitters. If she can’t care for him, he should be with us. Is this better for me? My mental health? My sanity? Probably not - ya girl loves her weeks “off”… but it’s better for HIM. Therein lies the sacrifice. I can only hope the reward is his health, safety and happiness. ⁣I can only hope that there would be benefits for all of us. ⁣
⁣⁣
It’s not easy. We don’t always like it or even agree. Yet here we are showing up for our kids and family like any other mother should. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So if you needed this pep talk too…⁣⁣
I’m sending you all love today and everyday. Even in the darkest season of sacrifice, I see you and I hope you find your light. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
You are loved.⁣⁣
You are valued.⁣⁣
You matter. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

I’ll never scorn a woman for making the decision that’s best for her…⁣
⁣
I saw on a recent Instagram post a stepmom getting heat from walking away from a 3 year relationship because her partner gained full custody. She didn’t want to be a full-time stepmom. My thoughts: good for her. ⁣
⁣
Why is her character put into question because she decided to walk away? If she stayed and struggled would she not hear “you knew what you were getting into”? Damned if you do and damned if you don’t…⁣
⁣
If a woman does some soul searching and realizes she doesn’t wasn’t the responsibility, the custody schedule, the chaos, the drama then good for her for being true and honest to herself. Sometimes the relationship with our partners doesn’t actually make it “worth it”. Sometimes the relationship needs work too and that’s the real problem. ⁣
⁣
I talk to my non-stepmom friends and hear “I could never do what you do.” Just like I look at marathon runners, it takes a certain type of crazy to want to put yourself through that 😂 I’m no runner, but damn I’m a strong stepmom. ⁣
⁣
For me, it will always come down to the happiness of the woman and if this stepmom life isn’t for you - you will get no shame from me here. ⁣
⁣✨Swipe for Bonus

And it’s freakin’ exhausting 🤣⁣
⁣
When my stepson tells me how amazing his mom is and how much fun he had. My face does this: 😁 but inside I’m 🙄🤢⁣
⁣
When my husband talks about a memory before me and details about the ex or my SS’s birth. My face: 🙂 but inside I’m 😩😓🤮⁣
⁣
When the ex makes a snide comment, minimizing my role or existence. My face: 🤐 but what I really want to do is 😤🤬⁣
⁣
There’s a lot of self control in stepmotherhood, right? In all these scenarios I have to put my own shit aside and think bigger picture. Not to say I’ve never let the inner stuff slip out on occasion, but for the most part I do handle my internal feelings privately - key point here is these feelings matter and deserve space, just not in the moment. My stepson doesn’t need to hear my thoughts on his mom, my husband deserves to share memories from his past that are important to him and the ex… well she doesn’t deserve the satisfaction of knowing she got to me. My feelings are valid but that’s part of my own inner growth. There’s a time and place, and yes it sucks being the “bigger person” but if stepmotherhood has taught me anything it’s grace. ⁣
⁣
Drop your emojis in comments. What does your face do vs. what’s inside? 🙃⁣

Peace won’t happen to you, but you can make it happen for yourself…⁣🕊️
⁣
We have to take ownership of what’s within our control and how we’re contributing. I encourage you to take inventory of what’s stealing your peace and what corrections you can make:⁣
⁣
Do you feel you and your partner are talking about the ex too much? Time to set boundaries of when and where you talk about her. ⁣
⁣
Have you lost some of your identity and feel your life revolves around being a stepmom? Get out and see your friends. Restart that hobby. Find yourself again. ⁣
⁣
Are you being too hard on yourself? Overthinking everything? Worried and anxious? ⁣
Tune into what you need and create your safe space. ⁣
⁣
One stupid simple thing I did was make 4 dozen muffins and froze them. Why? Because my SS likes my muffins and requests them every week but it stresses me out to make them every Monday … so I chose to work smarter not harder and that will preserve some peace. ⁣
⁣
Get creative, Mama’s. What can you do today to start caring more for your heart? ⁣
⁣⁣⁣

Every day unlocks a new fear😂😱⁣
⁣
Falling in love can be scary.⁣
Motherhood is scary. ⁣
Being a stepmom is absolutely terrifying. ⁣
⁣
Not knowing if you’re supposed to step up or step back. Should you try harder to bond with the kids? Navigating the dynamics with the ex, never knowing what’s coming next, feeling like you’re on edge and don’t have control?? wtf. ⁣
⁣
No one warns you, right? 🫣⁣
Deep breaths.⁣
We’re brave ass women. 😂⁣

You’re human and so are they….⁣♥️
⁣
We have to release ourselves from this duty. The role of making sure everyone is happy, or fixing the problems we didn’t create or aren’t even ours to fix. ⁣
⁣
My stepson is nearly 13 and boy is he getting moody. Sometimes it’s tangible and fixable, but more often than not he’s just having an off day. Don’t we all? ⁣
⁣
We can’t take everything personal. ⁣
It’s truly not all about us, thank goodness 😂⁣
⁣
So if you find yourself monitoring emotions, or trying to problem solve… take a breath. ⁣
⁣
They’re okay. ⁣
You’re okay. ⁣
⁣
Who needed this reminder? 🫶🏻⁣

A few years ago my husband said something pretty powerful…⁣
⁣
After one of my “why doesn’t she just give me a chance - I’m not a terrible person!!” rants, he looks me dead in the eye and said, “Babe, that’s what she’s afraid of.” He went on to say that it was probably easier for her to make me a monster in her head, and if she actually got to know me she would humanize me… maybe even LIKE me. 😱The horror! ⁣
⁣
This concept released me. Released me from the burden of trying to gain her approval. Released me from constantly wondering what I’ve done wrong or what I’ve done to deserve this - nothing and oh, nothing. He was right. If she got to know me, heard me out, saw me as a loving person in my SS’s life or even a loving person to my husband - well, she couldn’t handle it. I’m the villain in her story - and she’s committed to that narrative.⁣
⁣
I know it sucks to feel misunderstood and hated. I know you’re frustrated because you want to share your side of the story. I know you’re ruminating - knowing you would never behave like her. I get it…but I truly feel they’re choosing to see what they want to see, so nothing you do will change that. Only they can decide to change and I’m not holding my breath for that… are you? 😮‍💨⁣
⁣
Keep being amazing.💁🏻‍♀️⁣
Keep showing up and rocking it. 😎⁣
Keep your head high.👑⁣
Haters gonna hate.😘⁣

Sometimes our partners get defensive...⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
They hear us talk about their ex and they interpret it as blame. ⁣⁣⁣
They hear us talk about their kids and they interpret it as they’re bad parents. ⁣⁣⁣
They hear us talk about them and they interpret it as they’re bad partners. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Often times our complaints aren’t criticism, but rather an effort to reveal our emotional needs. Talking to our partners about our stepmom experience isn’t an attack on them, but an exercise in building connection and understanding. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Most of the couples that I work with are seeking the tools on how to communicate better and find that connection. If you want that extra support -  schedule with me and let’s work together.😘 ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
What has helped your partner understand your role? How can it be improved? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣
Want some extra help with connecting with your partner? Consider scheduling a 1:1 session with me or invite your partner! Comment “Couples” to learn more. 🫶🏻⁣
